title: mum gives birth car side
story: Mum gives birth in car on side of motorway after getting lost on way to hospitalBaby Delilah was born at the side of the A, and the road is recorded on her birth certicateLittle Delilah was born before they reached the hospital Image: MEN MEDIAByJoe Cusack:,  Nov | comments A mum gave birth in the front seat of a car on the side of the motorway after her own mum got lost on their way to hospital. Ali Bamford, , enlisted her mum Jane to drive her to hospital when she went into labour with her daughter at :am on October . But Ali’s mum had never driven the route to the hospital before and took a wrong turn on the way after a road closure. After a panic she started feeling like she needed to push, Baby Delilah was born at the side of the A. The road is even recorded on her birth certicate.  Mum of four, Ali, from Birstall, West Yorkshire, says: “I had moved house the year before so the route to the hospital was dferent than it had been for my other births. “Part of the motorway was closed so we had to come off at a dferent junction. I started telling Mum I had to push, and she told me she was lost and that I couldn’t push there was total panic in the car. It was so quick, I gave birth right there in the front seat and my mum had to unwrap the umbilical cord because it was all wrapped around my legs. “Delilah is doing really well now and I can’t wait to tell her the story when she’s older.” Ali and her partner, Jamie Firth, , met through his sister, Claire.  The pair have three older daughters, Scarlet, , Lillie, five, and two-year-old Thea. The three older girls were all born in hospital without drama. Ali had called her mum, Jane Wilding, , to take her hospital whilst Jamie remained at home with the other children. Ali says: “My mum arrived in her Renault Megane and she was keen to get going because she’d never driven the new route to the hospital before. “I was more relaxed, pottering about the house getting my bag ready, even though my contractions were about three minutes apart. “We set off, but part of the motorway was closed, and we had to come off at a junction we weren’t familiar with. The contractions suddenly became much stronger and mum was getting in a panic, trying to follow the Sat Nav whilst I was screaming in agony. “I told her the baby was coming and I’d have to push, and she was shouting: ‘You can’t push, we’re lost!’ It was complete chaos. “Mum came off at a slip road, without a clue where we were, and Delilah was born before she could even stop the car. I was wedged in the passenger seat and I caught Delilah in my arms. “Mum dashed round to the passenger side to unwrap the umbilical cord from round my legs. We were both in total shock. We didn’t know what to do. “Amazingly, we spotted a woman going past and she gave us directions to Pinderfields Hospital which was only about a mile away. “I wrapped Delilah in my dressing gown and Mum ran into A and E to get a team of nurses to come out. We hadn’t even cut the cord. It was a crazy hour.” Ali and Delilah remained in hospital for checks before being allowed home later that same afternoon. Three weeks on, both are now doing well. Ali says: “On Delilah’s birth certicate, it says she was born on the A, Carr Gate, West Yorkshire. “Mum was amazing I can’t thank her enough. She had to have the car valeted obviously, and she can’t sell it now – it holds too many precious memories.” Comment MORE ON HospitalsGiving birthSat-nav" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum heard crying help me
story: Mum heard crying ‘help me, I’m dying in heart-wrenching final  calls for helpBina Patel, , from Ashton-under-Lyne, Tameside, Manchester, was heard screaming ‘help me, I’m dying, I cant breathe’ as her son sat beside her and called for the ambulance ‘seven times’ as her condition deterioratedBina Patel was the most loving and caring person you could ever come across, says her son Image: Ashkay PatelByHelena VestyLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Nov | commentsA series of heart-wrenching  call recordings show how a beloved mum-of-two died after waiting ‘almost an hour’ for an ambulance to arrive. Bina Patel, , from Ashton-under-Lyne, Tameside, Manchester, was heard screaming ‘help me, I’m dying, I canapost breathe’ as her son sat beside her and called for the ambulance ‘seven times’ as her condition deteriorated. By the time paramedics got to her home, Bina already had ‘no pulse’, her son Ashkay said. In the weeks following his mother’s death, Ashkay, , is demanding answers and blames North West Ambulance Servicefor her death.He told Manchester Evening News that ‘my mum suffocated for almost an hourapos and that her le aposcould have been saved’.His comments came as new figures revealed patients suffering heart attacks and strokes in Greater Manchester are waiting for more than an hour for an ambulance amid crippling NHS pressure.On October  of this year, Bina, who had worked in the townaposs Asda as a well-known cashier for  years, had been out to meet friends in Leicester, before ing home and heading to bed. All seemed well and she was happy, her son said. But in the early hours of the morning of October , Ashkay woke to the horror of his mum shouting for his help, frightened that she was struggling to breathe. Ashkay claims his mother only had long-term diabetes, no unexpected, underlying conditions that would leave her short of breath. Together the pair, who shared a home after the death of Ashkay’s father, tried to calm Bina’s breathing - but to no avail. Bina began to progressively getting worse and just after .am, Ashkay said he made his first of seven calls to , asking for an ambulance. He said he was told that an ambulance would be on its way and that he should attempt to keep the patient calm, Ashkay said. Over the course of almost  minutes, Ashkay said he called  over and over as no ambulance was arriving and his mother was becoming severely ill.In recordings of two of the  calls, which Ashkay requested from NWAS , Bina’s heartbreaking distress can be heard. In the calls, she can be heard screaming, saying on multiple occasions ‘help me, I’m going to die’, with her screaming being acknowledged by the call handler as Ashkay tries to help his mother. The times of the calls, following the initial report at .am, were .am, .am, .am, .am, .am and another a few seconds later. NWAS provided recordings of the calls at .am and .am. During the call at ., the call handler can be heard saying that the wait for an ambulance is an ‘hour and a half’ as aposweaposre very busy’. In the second recording, from the call at .am, Ashkay tells the emergency service that his mother has now stopped breathing entirely. A call handler can be heard saying that there is ‘nothing’ Ashkay can do to help, and that he should wait for paramedics to arrive. The call handler then says they have ‘another call coming in and [they] have to hang up’. Ashkay said an ambulance and paramedic car arrived at .am, nearly an hour after his initial  call. By this point, he had been doing CPR as directed by the call handler to no effect and his mother was already dead, he said. A patient report completed by NWAS shows that an ambulance was mobile and on the way to the scene at .am. On paramedics’ arrival, Bina was showing aposno pulse, no respirationsapos and had a apossuspected cardiac arrestapos, reads the report. She was pronounced dead shortly after. Ashkay said he has been left aposscarredapos by the loss of his mother and the circumstances in which it happened. The pain is made all the worse by the fact that their home is a stone’s throw away from Tameside Hospital AE, he said.  Tameside Hospital is two minutes up the road from where we live,I could have got her in the car and driven her up there myself, I would have. But she just couldn’t. “At about .am, my mum was struggling to breathe. She shouted my name, I jumped out of bed and saw that she couldnapost even stand. She was wheezing, she looked dizzy. I sat her down, got her a glass of water and I called the ambulance at about .am to tell them she was having breathing dficulties. Knowing the hospital was so close, I expected someone to be there as soon as possible. No one arrived. I left it  minutes, her breathing was just getting more dficult and more dficult. Again, I called the ambulance service to chase, I explained that her breathing was becoming worse. She was screaming and screaming aposI canapost breathe, Iaposm going to dieapos. I genuinely thought she was going to die. I called them seven times that evening. It got to the point where she collapsed on the floor. I rang  and on my final  call at .am, they were telling me how to give CPR to my mum. At .am, five minutes later, thataposs when an ambulance and paramedic car arrived at the scene. They put adrenaline shots in her and put a machine on her and they did fight for her for a good  minutes. But it was too late by then, there was no pulse. I was so angry at them. I told them aposI rang you over an hour ago, thataposs when you should have been here, when she was still alive and just struggling for breath’. Now, Ashkay is demanding answers as to why an ambulance was only able to be mobilised to his home at .am, after he first called to report the breathing dficulties almost  minutes prior.  A le potentially could have been saved that night because she was struggling for breath for a full hour while waiting for the ambulance service, he said. Throughout that whole hour, her lips went from red to white, things I thought Iaposd never witness in my le. Every time I made a call, they kept saying aposcalm the patient downapos. How do you calm someone who is struggling to get breath  An hour before I was there, with my mum, trying to help her get her breath. An hour later, sheaposs lying in front of me, passed away. Iaposm traumatised because there was no help from the people I needed it from. The service that you and I pay into. None of it makes sense to me. Thereaposs unanswered questions, why was I let down  For anyone itaposs heartbreaking to see a parent die in front of you. That whole scenario is always going to be in the back of my mind, Iaposm never going to forget what I witnessed that night. Never in my le. Itaposs just scarred me for le. Knowing the NHS wasnapost there when I needed it. I canapost trust the ambulance service at all. No one can believe the ambulance took that long. The first question the  call handler asks is aposis the patient breathing ’ She just suffocated for that whole hour, imagine being underwater for a full hour, youaposre not going to survive. Thataposs the position the ambulance [service] put her in. If they came in time, something could have been done. The fact that I had to call  to get instructions on how to give CPR to my own mother, itaposs sickening. NWAS is the reason my mum died, in my opinion, they caused her death by not coming in time. I feel like they killed her, I blame them for her death. They didnapost do their jobs properly. I donapost think they took it seriously enough.” NWAS is now doing internal enquiries into the incident, said Ashkay, and has promised him a response within  days. A North West Ambulance Service spokesperson said: “We wish to pass on our deepest sympathies to Mr Patel and his family for the loss of his mother. “We can confirm we have received an official complaint, and the investigation is ongoing. We are in contact with the family and will update them with our findings.” Ashkay and his brother are now left mourning the loss of their beloved mother and are to raising money in her memory for their local temple and the British Heart Foundation. Bina Patel was so well known in the community , Ashkay said. She was the most loving and caring person you could ever come across. Any help and guidance you ever needed, she was there. Even now people are coming to my house talking about the happy times they had with her, I had with her. My mum did the best she could, throughout her entire le. She was so proud of my brother and I and what weaposve achieved. She made Indian feasts for the local homeless shelter, her speciality was cooking, no one is going to cook that feast anymore. She was an amazing person that could connect with anyone in the world. Youaposll never find a character like her, my mum was spectacular.”If you would like to donate to the fundraiser in memory of Bina Patel, head to the JustGiving page. title: mum living mould ridden house
story: Mum living in mould-ridden house with three kids told just leave by vicar landlordSarah Richards has rented from Rev Ian Livingston for the last five years, the last four of which she claims have been spent living inside mouldy wallsSarah Richards was told by landlord Rev Ian Livingston to move out when she asked him to fix a damp problem Image: Sarah RichardsByEdward Church:,  Nov | commentsA mum raising her three children in a property with black mould claims she is living a “nightmare” as her vicar landlord refuses to address the problem.Sarah Richards, , has rented from Rev Ian Livingston for the last five years, the last four of which she claims have been spent living inside mouldy walls.But the mum claims that whenever she has complained about the damp conditions, she is shrugged off by her landlord who tells her to just “move out”. Sarah, who lives with her three kidsas well as her partner, says she noticed the mould about a year after moving in, but at first, did not know what it was. Once she realised it was mould, she “tried everything” to get rid of it. Cleaning didn’t work, neither did opening the windows, putting the heating on - or any other home remedy for mould. Speaking toCornwall Live , she realised it was being caused by damp and had spread across the house.“It was in every single room,” Sarah said. “Even in the hallway. In the kitchen, my bedroom, the girlsapos room. I saw in theirs the wallpaper had begun to pull down with damp under there. “When environmental health came they ran their hand down the wall and it was soaking.” Pictures taken by Sarah showed the extent of the mould problem. It coats the lower walls of most rooms, and is particularly shocking against the pink wallpaper of her childrenaposs bedroom. Sarah said that the issue has persisted for the past four years. The damp flares up several times a year, she said, getting worse in the cold and wet months. WIth the colder months came more black mould. Sarah reported the issue to environmental health around six months after first discovering the damp - having hoped she could fix it herself at first - and then contacted Rev Livingston, the landlord. She said he was extremely unhappy she had called in professional help and refused to fix it. He continued to tell her he will not fix anything and that the house is entirely her responsibility. When asked what Sarah should do, he suggested she simply move out. “Move out with what funds ” Sarah continued, “I can’t just up and move, I don’t have themoneyfor that.And besides, have you tried to find somewhere to live in Cornwall  “I’m on every site, I’m on the list for Coastline Housing. I’m putting myself out there but I can’t. “It’s a nightmare, my daughter is mildly asthmatic and it gets worse with the mould. My other kids never used to get coughs but now they’re always spluttering. “My partner has breathing issues and it makes it worse too. I am afraid of people coming over to my house.  “It’s not messy, but the mould makes me feel like it’s dirty and disgusting.” The mould was last reported around a week and a half ago. CornwallLive approached Rev Livingston for a response to Sarah’s complaints, but he declined to comment. title: mums horror after watching girl
story: Mums horror after watching girl, , on scooter killed in hit-and-run by schoolIt is understood that the victim was wheeling across Reddings Lane at around :pm after leaving school early - when she was hit by a Ford GalaxyThe girl tragically died in hospital from her injuries Image: Tristan Potter   SWNSByBradley StokesJonathan ColesNews Reporter:,  Nov A little girl was scooting across a zebra crossing when a hit and run driver allegedly ploughed into her - as her mum watched on. The three-year-old, who has not yet been named, died following the collision in Yardley, Birmingham on Thursday. It is understood that she was wheeling across Reddings Lane at around :pm after leaving the Olive School early - when she was hit by a Ford Galaxy. She was rushed to hospital but later died from her injuries. Police say the driver of the silver car did not stop, but a man was later arrested on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving. And witnesses on Friday said the the mum of the victim watched on as the horror incident happened.Do you know what happened  Do you know the victim  Email webnews@mirror.Mohammed aposAliapos Hussain, who lives on nearby Weston Lane, said: I didnapost seen anything but my we saw a bit of the incident but then police were moving people from the area. It was a three-year-old girl who had been picked up by her mother from school slightly early. The young girl was on a scooter and made it   of the way into the zebra crossing already and the mum was at the zebra crossing - she witnessed the whole thing. We didnapost know the girl, but have placed flowers outside the schools. Itaposs really sad. Other locals have claimed the road is a rat run - and drivers regularly go over the speed limit. It is thought that the zebra crossing where the girl died is used by pupils and parents from three schools: Yardley Secondary School, Olive Schooland Al-Furqan Primary School, all within  yards of each other. There is only one set of traffic lights which is for the intersection of Battery Way and Reddings Lane. One neighbour, who lives directly opposite Olive School - a school which only opened this year - said: This area is a total rat run. Cars just belt across, not even taking into consideration of the mph speed limit. I didnapost witness the event, but heard a police sirens when the incident took place at around .. How the council gave planning permission to build another school on this road I do not know. It just gets too busy. The air ambulance landed on the park which is just behind Al-Furqan Primary School. We didnapost know the girl, but I know she was three-years-old. Opposite Olive School is Royal Food and Wine Off-Licence, Winston Fernando was working when the incident happened. He said: When they opened Olive School about eight months ago, when they finish the school day, the all use the one zebra crossing - that is for Yardley School too.  There are no signal lights only the one traffic light at the intersection, that is it. The problem is that the amount of traffic that accumulates at the end of the school day - for three schools - is horrendous. You have cars parked where they shouldnapost, I have even saw cars parked on the zebra crossing. People donapost care, you can see that it is the end of the school day and it is busy - still they drive straight through. Whoever did, did not stop he just carried on driving through like nothing had happened. People moan about the school being here, itaposs too late now. This awful incident has happened and the school is there. The council must do more. I saw lots of police and ambulance here when the three year old girl was struck, she was then taken to the park when she was taken to hospital by air ambulance. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information and changes at www.mirror email .Another neighbour, who lives nearly Yardley School, did not wintess the incident but said: When the schools finish, it is totally manic around here. Loads of cars park up: on pavements, in side streets, even on the zebra crossing itself. It comes to a total standstill, then you have traffic waiting from the busy Battery Way. Unfortunately, something like this was bound to happen at some point. It is quite a small area, with roads with no driveways, to have three schools in. West Midlands Police said on Thursday that officers had arrested a man, aged , on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving. A statement said: It is understood the girl was using a zebra crossing when she was hit by a silver Ford Galaxy just before .pm today . The driver of the car failed to stop at the crossing but officers swtly took witness accounts and statements, and arrested a -year-old man on suspicion of causing death by dangerous driving after locating his vehicle in the area.  The girl’s family were with her at the time of the tragedy. Acting Insp Paul Hughes added: The tragic death of such a young child is deeply saddening. Our thoughts are with the girl’s family at this incredibly distressing time. Our priority is supporting her family and ensuring that a thorough investigation is carried out. We understand the shock and worry this may have caused the community and ask people not to speculate on the circumstances. I’m keen to hear from anyone who was on Reddings Lane or the immediate vicinity and may have witnessed the collision or heard anything that may assist our investigation.Mohammed, whose we is said to have witnessed the incident, has set up a fundraising page for the victimaposs family.As a father I understand and feel their pain. The family must be going through some dficulties at the moment, that is why I have set up a fundraising page. I am trying to reach £ and so far at £. A spokesman for the Olive School said: We send our sincere sympathy to the bereaved family at this incredibly sad time. We are supporting our pupils, staff and the school community as they grieve.Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON EducationSchoolsDangerous drivingCrime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: one food you should eat
story: One food you should eat twice a week to help you avoid high cholesterolHigh cholesterol is an important problem in the UK with its connection to coronary heart disease and here are some foods and other tips to keep it under controlCertain foods work well in reducing peoples high cholesterol Image: Getty ImagesBySarah BarrettTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsBrits are being warned of the dangers from high cholesterol with statistics showing a worrying number of over s in this position and here are some foods and tips to reduce it. Statistics from the British Heart Foundation show that every eight minutes somebody dies from coronary heart disease and the importance to take steps to keep the organ healthy.High cholesterol is extremely common and it increases your risk of heart attack and disease, so it is crucial to keep it at a healthy level, reported the Irish Mirror.For good heart health and healthy cholesterol, the BHF recommends people have a diet with fruit and vegetables, and less fatty food.  What is High Cholesterol  Cholesterol is a type of fat found in your blood which is made in the body mainly by the liver and it is needed for all body cells to produce important hormones. Butthere is too much cholesterol in your blood, it sticks to your artery walls to form atheroma or plaque. This build-up on the artery walls means your arteries become narrowed and this process also called the hardening of the arteries. If an artery supplying the heart muscle becomes blocked completely, the muscle becomes damaged and this is known as a heart attack. Similarlyan artery to the brain is completely blocked, it damages the brain and this is called a stroke.  Symptoms of High Cholesterol High cholesterol in itself does not usually cause symptoms but the build-up of fatty material on the artery walls and the narrowing does leave to ious conditions and these depend on where the blockage occurs.Angina Acute coronary syndrome Heart attackthe heart is affected Stroke or TIAthe brain is affected Leg pain and intermittent pain when walkingthe peripheral arteries are affected.The body can produce all the cholesterol it needs and can usually maintain a healthy level of blood cholesterol. Good cholesterolHDL cholesterol is called good cholesterol or healthy cholesterol because it mops up cholesterol left behind in your arteries and carries it to your liver where it is broken down and passed out of your body. Regular physical activity and exercise can help increase your HDL level but problems arise when the balance goes wrong and there is an increase in bad cholesterol called LDL. This may result from inherited problems or from eating too much saturatedfat or too many foods from the top shelf of the Food Pyramid.  Bad cholesterolLDL cholesterol travels from your liver through your arteries to other parts of your body. LDL is called bad cholesterol because it sticks to the walls in your arteries - making them narrow. Prevention If you want to prevent high cholesterol here are some things you can do.You should have regular blood pressure and cholesterol checks with your doctor. Eat more fruit and vegetables and wholegrain foods Eat less fatty foods Eat fish twice a week including oily fish If you smoke, try to stop Be a healthy weight Be more physically active for at least  minutes  days a week Drink less alcohol Learn to relax, de-stress – take time out for yourself.Comment MORE ON Blood pressureHeart attackHeart diseaseFitnessCholesterol" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: pensioner left scaffolding around house
story: Pensioner left with scaffolding around house after free renovation abandonedJudith Chamberlain, of Beeston, has told how E.On have abandoned insulation work that comes as part of a government grant scheme and left scaffolding around her homeJudith Chamberlain, of Beeston, has told how she has been left with scaffolding around her homeByJoel MooreTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsA pensioner says utility firm E.On started insulation work on her home and then abandoned it, leaving scaffolding around the house.Judith Chamberlain, of Beeston, said that the scaffolding has now been left for more than a month as well as building materials in her garden, reported NottinghamshireLive.She said she was left frustrated and deflated by the situation especially after receiving a government grant for the improvements in the first place. Iaposm back to square one, basically, she said. I felt pretty deflated, but I suppose this is le. Itaposs been a bit of a journey really. Itaposll be a relief to get the scaffolding down and then Iaposll be able to resurrect my garden.  Ms Chamberlain said scaffolding was put up around her home in early October, with alterations to be made to external pipework and building materials put in her front and back gardens. By the end of the month I was told that the project had ended, she continued. God knows how much government money has been wasted in the process. Ms Chamberlain was due to have external wall insulation for free after she successfully applied for a Green Homes Grant, a scheme funded by the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy. The grants have been handed out and the work is being carried out in phases. Ms Chamberlain applied for a grant in March, but she claims E.On said they would be unable to finish the work before a deadline at the end of October. The company said this was due to the fact they were trying to complete work for as many homes as possible in the window after applications closed on March . E.On said they had apologised to Ms Chamberlain and would remove the building materials and fix the pipework as a matter of urgency. A spokesperson told NottinghamshireLive: Unfortunately it wasn’t possible to complete the external wall insulation at this property under the government-led Green Homes Grant Local Authority Delivery scheme before this phase of it closed. We have made the council’s local co-ordinator for this work across Nottinghamshire aware of this case so the insulation can be completed within a future phase of the scheme.” Ms Chamberlain said that she believed she was not the only homeowner to fall foul of the timeout. E.On said they have provided  energy efficiency measures to  Nottinghamshire households at a government-funded cost of £,. title: sas who dares wins star
story: SAS: Who Dares Wins star who heard we being kned to death weds new loveSAS: Who Dares Wins star Danny Cross was forced to listen on the phone as Nicola was murdered by schizophrenic Marcin Porczynski as she protected her kids who survived the horror kne attackDanny Cross, , has found love with new we Alex WellsByGraeme Murray:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsAn SAS: Who Dares Wins star who heard his we being kned to death has married his new love. Danny Cross was devastated when we Nicola, , was savagely killed protecting their children after an intruder broke into their home in . Now Cross, , has found love with new we Alex Wells and described her as his “gt from heaven” for helping him after the heartbreak The pair have also started a family together after their baby girl was born in July. The SAS: Who Dares Wins star was forced to listen on the phone as Nicola was murdered by schizophrenic Marcin Porczynski as she protected her kids.  Now an IT specialist, Cross revealed the heartache he endured and new love in podcast Anything Goes With James English. The dad-of-three said: “It is six years since we lost Nicola. Itaposs been dficult but at the moment le is good. Iaposve just had a baby. None of this was ever the plan but thataposs part of le - and you have to somehow try your best.” He spoke about his new we, saying: “When we first met she had just taken a new job to do child mental health. It was like a gt from heaven, I couldnapost have asked for anyone better to be involved with.  “She wasnapost one of the professional people put in to help us, but sheaposs helped us probably more than she will ever realise.” In the podcast, he also spoke about the night he heard Nicola being murdered in . Cross was  miles at the time but heard the horric sound of her being murdered down the phone while sitting in a hotel room While she was on the phone he broke through the back door, Cross said: “Instantly I screamed and leapt out of the bed because I knew someone was in there. “I grabbed the hotel phone and dialled  but it didnapost work. So, I tried again and got through to the local police and I could hear Nicky on the phone with some screams. She was pushing, struggling, that kind of stuff.  I could hear what was going on which was horrendous. There were so many thoughts going on in my mind at the time. I think deep down, I knew something awful would have happened just because of the nature of the screams on the phone. I assumed Nicky was dead and thought the kids were next and I just lost control. “I remember screaming down the phone to this poor  operator that she was going to be responsibleanything happened to my kids because she didnapost act quick enough. “It wasnapost her fault but as soon as I put the phone down to her, I kept the line open to Nick, just talking to her. I said aposstay with meapos and aposI know you can hear me, just please donapost go donapost leave me.apos I couldnapost get up off the floor. “My legs had gone completely numb. I was just dragging myself up to the bed trying to make my legs work and I remember just hitting my legs with fists trying to get some feeling into them so I could get up and go downstairs to reception and start seeing what was going on.  “Eventually I just sat down in the hotel reception shaking. I couldnapost control my arms. I was still talking to Nicola on the phone then all of a sudden, I heard children crying on the phone so I knew my children were alive at least. But I could hear them saying mummy wake up. I heard the paramedics arrive with the police and thataposs when I cut the line off, I didnapost want to listen anymore.” Porczynski admitted killing Nicola on the grounds of diminished responsibility and was detained for an indefinite period at a secure psychiatric unit. Cross told BBC Three Counties Radio: Iaposm engaged to Alex. Sheaposs a remarkable woman. Weaposre moving forward and hopefully going to get married next year. The children are really happy.He worked with ex-Special Forces hardmen Jason Fox and Ant Middleton and spoke about the harrowing night he lost Nicola . The star later set up the charity StrongMen which helps others who have been impacted by crime. It arranges weekend retreats for bereaved men to do outdoor activities and speak to others affected by grief. title: schoolgirl 11 who woke up
story: Schoolgirl, , who woke up with a belly ache dies just three weeks laterJohn Woods daughter, Carly, was taken to hospital after she started to feel worse and doctors gave her family a devastating diagnosis - she had a rare form of liver cancerCarly Woods died just three weeks after complaining to her parents she had a belly acheByLee Grimsditch:,  Nov | commentsA schoolgirl who woke up one day with a stomach ache died just three weeks later, her devastated father says. John Woodsapos -year-old daughter, Carly, had been playing outside with her friends and brothers and was her aposnormal happy selfapos the day before she felt unwell. She was taken to hospital after she started to feel worse and doctors gave her family a devastating diagnosis - she had a rare form of liver cancer.Her liver was four times larger than it should have been and it was ram packed and stuffed with multiple tumours, John, , told the Liverpool Echo. Carly, whose family lives in Skelmersdale, died on November  at Alder Hey Childrenaposs Hospital.  John, who lives in with his partner, Kelly [Carlyaposs mum], and their children, said: She woke up on the Sunday morning and said, aposdad, Iaposve got a belly acheapos. I was putting clothes away and I just said, wellyouaposre trying to get out of school Iaposm still sending you. It was her first year in senior school and she was having a bit of trouble settling in. I thought she was trying to play on it. As the day went on she was moaning a little bit more and I asked her what sheaposd had for her breakfast this morning. She said she wasnapost really hungry. I said youaposve probably got hunger pains, get downstairs and Iaposll do you your dinner.  I did her something to eat but she didnapost really eat much of it. It got to bed time and she was whimpering a little bit so Kelly just gave her some Ibuprofen. Kelly come back in the bedroom and said I think she might have appendicitis. I said weaposll see how she gets on tomorrow morning. At five oaposclock in the morning, my partner wakes me and says can you take the day off and watch the baby, Iaposm going to take her to the hospital. Carly was taken to Ormskirk Hospital where she underwent scans and tests. Appendicitis was ruled out but the parents were told their daughteraposs liver was bigger than it should be and doctors didnapost understand the reason why. Carly was in hospital for four days undergoing more tests until she was eventually transferred to Alder Hey. It was there that further scans prompted doctors to break some devastating news to her parents. John said: I was called into the office and the doctor told me that straight away they could see on the ultrasound her liver was four times larger than it should be and it was just ram packed and stuffed with multiple tumours. John said the news left them in shock but worse was to come as further tests showed that the cancer had spread to the little girlaposs lungs.  Carly had been diagnosed with a rare type of liver cancer called aposhepatocellular neoplasm not otherwise specied HC-NOSapos. John said: They said they only see one or two of these cancers each year and normally thereaposs some sort of pre-warning, usually the kid has been in hospital or been sick before. Doctors told the parents they would need to administer an invasive and experimental form of chemotherapy immediately to rid Carlyaposs lungs of tumours before she would be able to have a liver transplant. Surgery was performed to prepare Carly for the chemotherapy by inserting a line in the side of her neck, but afterwards doctors were having trouble bringing her around. After she eventually woke up, Carlyaposs parents were told they would have to get her salt levels higher before they could administer the treatment and so the parents went home for the night.  The next day, a doctor called them both back into the hospital. John said: We went back in on the Sunday morning and they told us there was medically nothing they could do. Her liver was pretty much clapped out and not ing. She wouldnapost physically be able to take the chemotherapy, it would be too cruel. They told us that we would have to make the decision to not resuscitate her and just keep her comfortable and let her pass. Carly lived for another week before she died, surrounded by her loving parents, on November . John said: I think for both of us itaposs not even sunk in yet. Iaposm still numb. The only thing thataposs getting me through it is making it [Carlyaposs funeral] the best day possible for her.The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  Weaposre having horses and carriages with the horses dressed as unicorns because that was one of her favourite things. She was a bubbly little girl. Everyone knew her for having wild hair. She always had a smile on her face and her teachers said to me she was always complimenting somebody. The grieving dad said the thing thataposs giving them comfort at this time, is knowing that samples taken from Carly may help other children. John added: I hope Carlyaposs memory and story will be seen by thousands and her sacrice will potentially save thousands of familyaposs from the same heart ache and fate in the future. title: single mum two living abandoned
story: Single mum-of-two living in abandoned block with kids sleeps with kne under bedThe tenant, who is a survivor of domestic abuse and has asked for anonymity, lives with her teenage son and baby daughter - and says she is terried in her "extremely dangerous" building in East LondonThe woman says she is scared to stay in the abandoned blockByRuby Gregory:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA single mum-of-two says she sleeps with a kne under her bed at night because she is terried in her extremely dangerous building.The tenant, who is a survivor of domestic abuse and has asked for anonymity, lives with her teenage son and baby daughter,She says the trio are the only people still living in the abandoned block in East London - which leaves her fearing for her safety. The mum, , shares a bed with her son, , and daughter, aged  months, because she doesnapost want her son to be scared at night.She first moved into the property with her son in , reports MyLondon.It was a fresh start for the family, after she fled a violent partner and was homeless.Do you have a similar story  Email webnews@mirror.  However in , she claims she was handed a letter by Clarion Housing explaining she must leave because the entire building was extremely dangerous. She said: I received a letter saying I needed to decamp, the building is extremely dangerous - a housing officer promised me that we would get support. A lot of the tenants were tricked into homes because they were non-English speakers, they didnapost understand the process. They were worried they’d be out on the streets, and now I’m the last one here. The process is by being placed into temporary accommodation or permanent housing found by Clarion. However, the mum is refusing to move into the permanent and temporary accommodation previously offered by Clarion because she fears she will be living in temporary housing with her kids for years. What Clarion do is they lie, they cheat people and put them in temporary accommodation and just leave them there for years - rotting, she alleged. Because the mum rejected Clarionaposs options of living in a crime ridden estate nearby and out of borough in Walthamstow, Clarion served her a notice of possession orderlast March. She says she was horried when a senior housing officer reportedly told her in a later meeting: Itaposs social housing, what do you expect  While suffering a miscarriage a few weeks ago, the mum was notied by Clarion that they will be taking her to court because the six-month notice of their possession order period had ended. She believes Clarion is responsible for her recent miscarriage at nine-and-a-half weeks, and wants to sue them for violating her human rights. Breaking down in tears, the mum said: I was so happy when I moved in - now Iaposm in a really bad state. I don’t want to live in a squalor now, I just don’t want to be living like this. It’s my fourth Christmas stuck here, for New Years we’ll be stuck here - everyone  apart from Clarion tenants will be enjoying themselves. I’m just here on my own, it’s crazy, no neighbours, no one to look out for you, it’s just awful. She claims the communal hallways now reek of urine and gone-off food because no maintenance staff have tended to the building since . While faulty fire alarms means the family are often woken up past midnight to the sound of extremely loud fire alarms. for our daily newsletter to keep up to date with all the essential information and changes at www.mirror email .On one occasion, firefighters had to break a door down with a crowbar because they couldnapost get in. She also no longer receives post, including vital food vouchers for her toddler. There’s hardly any food in the house, I’m really, really struggling, the mum said. She continued: It’s really hard, everywhere you turn to, they should be safeguarding us, they just turn your back on you - whether it’s the councillor, the local MP, Citizens Advice Bureau, HSC, Environmental Health - they just send emails here and there, things are going round in circles, but nothingaposs being done. It’s really depressing, it’s had a really bad impact on my physical health, I’ve had a miscarriage now because of all of this stress. I don’t sleep at night, I don’t eat. I’m a zombie because I’m working all day. I’ve got a baby that’s  months old who’s sick, I’m on my own and people just don’t have any regard. Inside the two-bed flat, the mum says itaposs extremely stuffy with little air because the windows have never opened very far, while a mice infestation is re. Itaposs taken a toll on the womanaposs teenage son too, who suffers from thalassemia, a blood cell disorder that produces less haemoglobin than usual - causing fatigue and brittle bones. Describing her sonaposs patience, she says: My son has stopped asking me about our situation now as he’s seen how it’s affected me. He sees that and knows it hurts me. He’s a good boy and doesn’t pressurise me much. He says, aposmum don’t worry, we’re not always going to live like this, I promise you I’ll study hard and I’ll get you out of hereapos. Since the pandemic hit, the mum says her housing situation has gone out of control, itaposs also been a struggle to maintain her hair and beauty business - a business sector that was hit hard by Covid-. I’m not expecting luxury like Kensington and Cha, I just want a normal house where me and my kids can heal, she adds. A Clarion spokesperson said: When Lemon Tree House was determined as unsafe in , we worked closely with all residents to find them suitable alternative accommodation. We have offered the resident a number of suitable properties, including both temporary and permanent options. The safety and wellbeing of our residents is our number one priority and there are approved fire safety measures in place in the building. We remain committed to working with the resident to find a permanent home. news uk-news stubborn-dog-refuses-leave-car-"Golden retriever Lenny stubbornly refuses to get out carByTfany LoVideo News ReporterGraeme Murray:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA stubborn golden retriever refused to leave the car despite his owneraposs pleas, a cute video shows.Sam Dawson says her pet pooch Lenny, has a mind of his own and she demonstrated his determination not to exit the vehicle in a video thataposs gone viral on Facebook.The amusing clip, shows the dog remaining on the back seat and just looks a his owner Sam who tells him: Lenny, itaposs time to go inside. Time to go to the house, come on. The animal leans his head against the door frame and blinks a few times but fails to carry out her instructions. The dog is determined to remain put inside the car despite his owner begging him to get out.Many golden retriever owners found the clip hilarious and described Lennyaposs performance a classic golden move according to the Daily Star.One said: Oh boy, been there, done that. We know whoaposs in charge here.apos Another added: Oh I get it Lenny. Thataposs how I feel about going back to work. Some dog owners agreed their golden retrievers acted exactly the same as Lenny every time they were taken on a car journey. A viewer said: Oh my God, my dog was the same. He just wanted to hang out in the truck so I would leave him there unless it was hot. Another commented: The ride was not long enough. You have to drive around the block again, and again, and again. They are definitely stubborn. But they are lucky they are so damn cute. title: tardis house goes sale 600000
story: Tardis house goes on sale for £, despite being narrower than London busThe one-bed property in Notting Hill, London, is deceptively small from the outside, but once the lucky owner has entered the building, theyll find a surprisingly roomy maisonette over two floorsThe one-bed property in Notting Hill, London is deceptively small from the outside of the property Image: Homesite RightmoveByGraeme Murray:,  Nov A Tardis house has gone on sale for £k despite parts of it being narrower than a London bus. At first glance it looks like a little outbuilding and you wouldnapost expect it to be a house. But the one-bed property in Notting Hill is deceptively small from the outside - similar to Doctor Whoaposs police box Tardis which is actually huge on the inside. And once the lucky owner has entered the building, theyaposll find a surprisingly roomy maisonette over two floors. It has been designed to maximise the space available and both the bedroom and kitchen are slimmer than a London bus. A little living room is the first ting prospective buyers will encounter when they come through the door, complete with a cosy sofa and widescreen TV.  Shelves help maximise the space without bulky furniture. And next to that is sleek, modern kitchen, with hob laid fitted microwave at head height.It is being marketed by Homesite, Notting Hill, on Rightmove aposs property site.The owner, in the fashionable area, has built a breakfast bar below a window. A skylight above, meanwhile, allows plenty of sunshine in and makes the room look bigger.  Agents Homesite say the property is based in Powis Mews, where homes can fetch £.million, and they say it has much to recommend it. The brochure states: Itaposs located a stoneaposs throw away from the market, boutiques and cafes of Portobello Road and Westbourne Grove. Sliding doors take the viewer to the little bedroom which measures just ft in across compared to a Routemaster bus which is ft in wide.  A double bed is lit by pendant-style lightbulbs which shine above the mattress The current owner has not cluttered the home with furniture and instead relies on built-in wardrobes and shelving. The estate agent adds: The apartment has a modern fully fitted kitchen with brand new Siemens appliances. The ground floor level benefits from high ceilings, large sash windows, a skylight and bespoke carpentry with a feature spiral staircase.  The lower ground level consists of a study area with built in wardrobes, a separate bedroom area and family bathroom that has been finished to an exceptional standard. The capital is well-known for its creative solutions to maximise space. One trendy flat in an upscale postcode is on the market for a knock-down price, it was on for a rental price of£ a week. It boasted a large shower, opposite the kitchenette, but there was no toilet to be seen.  Elsewhere, a double room in Finsbury, in north of the city, was on the market for £ a month, but the new tenant had no bedroom It provided a mattress beneath its eaves, with a hammock slung nearby There was also a large garden and a movie room set up. But any renter will need to share with more than  other people, as well as three cats. title: tenant branded scum landlord after
story: Tenant branded scum by landlord after she refused to pay final months rentJayde Madle controversially told her flats owner to use the deposit as her final payment before moving from London to the US this month, believing he wouldn’tthe bond eventhe property was spotlessJayde Madle, who was branded scum in a hateful rant from landlord after she refused to pay final months rentByAdam Wareing:,  Nov | commentsA tenant was branded ‘scum’ by her landlord after a financial dispute, in which she refused to pay her final month’s rent and told him to use her deposit instead. Jayde Madle controversially told her flataposs owner to use the deposit as her final payment before moving from London to the US this month, believing he wouldn’tthe bond eventhe property was spotless.The move angered the landlord, who hit back at her scheme by calling her a “liar” as well as “greedy and spoiled”apos, so she shamed him on Twitter by sharing a screengrab of his scathing rant.The former University of Westminster student has since split the internet with her bold move, with many praising her and claiming his rant is evidence heaposd aposalready spent her depositapos. Others have sympathised with the unknown property owner and claimed Jayde should pay the final monthaposs rent as itaposs aposwhat everyone signs up toapos. Her posts brand the landlord a “cowboy” and claim she was forced to act as he aposstole previous tenantsapos depositsapos and hers wasnapost registered on a Government-approved tenancy deposit protection scheme.The landlordaposs scathing WhatsApp response said: My thoughts on you  Jayde you are lower than scum and people laugh at you. You are a liar, arrogant, snidey, greedy, and spoilt and I would be embarrassed to be associated with you. Maybe you are just immature and will grow out of it. Good riddance. Jayde insisted sheaposs never had issues with a landlord before and even goes for drinks with one of her previous flataposs owners, but says the message she shared was aposjust the tip of the icebergapos. Her tweets have more than , likes and theyaposve split opinion, with some suggesting her plan is aposheroicapos while others claim she should pay the final monthaposs rent. Jaydeaposs post said: My landlord just messaged me this because I asked him to use my deposit as my last monthaposs rent so he canapost steal half for made up reasons like he has with every other tenant. Not this tweet ending up on landlord Twitter. Please stop chiming inyouaposve not read everything, I wouldnapost have done thishe used the tenancy deposit scheme . Iaposve rented in London for the past five years and never had an issue with a landlord before. @Rydel commented: Your deposit isnapost meant to be used as a final rent unless it was agreed in writing. He should have taken six weeks off you. Poor guy. One user named Matt said: I donapost agree with this message but also the rent should be paid until you leave and then the deposit edthe property is in order. This is all set out from the start. Itaposs what everyone signs up to. However other users backed her plan and suggested his sweary reaction to it suggested he would never have ed her deposit in the first place. Redwoman: This is top landlord-shafting. I trust your judgement that youaposd have never seen your deposit again. I didnapost see either of mine when I rented. Good work.  A user called Seanie said: He wasnapost so embarrassed to be associated with you when you were paying off his mortgage. Simon added: Iaposm calling that game, set and match to you. Very well played. Another user added: Tell me your landlord plans on stealing the deposit without telling me your landlord plans on stealing your deposit. Thereaposs no way he would react like thishis intentions are good. A user called Fred said: Oh dear me, I think heaposs very angry with you because your deposit money was going to be spent on his Christmas. That means youaposve just ruined his Christmas. Heroic move. UK law states landlords must put tenantsapos deposits in a government-approved tenancy deposit schemewithin  days of receiving it. Jayde has been contacted for comment. news uk-news thomas-markle-says-meghan-deceived-"Thomas Markle glad the truth is coming out about MeghanByMilo BoydNews ReporterLorraine KingNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov Meghan Markleaposs estranged father says she aposdeceivedapos people by claiming she had not giving authorisation to a senior aide to brief the authors of her biography. Thomas Markle slammed his daughter following revelations from her then press secretary Jason Knauf that she was aware about the book Finding Freedom. The Duchess of Sussex said she had not remembered emails between her and Mr Knauf despite a spokesperson for the Sussexes insisting they did not collaborate with the authors on the book, nor were they interviewed for it In a damning interview on GB News on Thursday evening, he claimed: I cant speak to much about this but I think she was trying to deceive.  I think she was telling lies. Finally the truth is coming out and thank god for Jason Knauf. I would like him to come over so I can take him out for a steak. Meghan has apologised in a new witness statement, where she accepted that Mr Knauf did brief the authors of Finding Freedom with Meghanaposs knowledge. She said: I apologise to the Court for the fact that I had not remembered these exchanges at the time. I had absolutely no wish or intention to mislead the Defendant or the Court.  The Duchess added that had she known about the emails she would have been more than happy to refer to them as strongly supportive of her case.In the interview Thomas claimed Meghan had demanded he stopped talking to his two older children and that she had ghosted her family from both sides after marrying Prince Harry.Meghan has claimed that her two older half-siblings Samantha and Thomas had said hurtful things about her in the past.  The interview this evening comes as the Associated Newspapers Limited - the publishers of the Mail on Sunday - appeals against a summary judgement given earlier this year. Meghan had sued the company over five articles that reproduced parts of a personal and private letter sent to her dad in August . The High Court ruled ANLaposs publication of Meghanaposs letter to her father was unlawful, meaning there was no need for a trial. Mr Markle last appeared on British TV screens at the end of October when he was interviewed on Good Morning Britain.  The show was subsequently hit with a  Ofcom complaints by viewers unhappy that he had sounded off about his estranged daughter once again. The Duchess of Sussex has been the subject of a number of cutting remarks from her father and he also tore into Prince Harryaposs new tell-all book, which he branded shameful.  During the attack on the Sussexes Thomas claimed he was being ghosted by Meghan and has vowed to continue to publicly attack his daughter until she begins speaking to him again. I think Harry has abandoned the Queen, the royal family, the British people and the Army. Heaposs abandoned them all, he said on GMB. I’ve made it quite clear until I hear from her until she does speak to me that I’ll continue to do this.  I will do a show for at least a monthI can get it through and eventually sooner or later she should start talking to me - this is way too childish. This is kind of silly. It’s time to talk with each other. We’re family. At one point the retired lighting director said heaposd considered taking legal action in a bid to see his grandchildren, Archie and Lilibet. Some viewers found that suggestion galling. Thereaposs something quite tone deaf about Thomas Markle, one person wrote on social media. Surely youaposd know that your daughter has cut you off because you keep bashing her to the press  How can you be that unaware  The last time Mr Markle went on GB News was back in August this year.  He was asked by Wootton for his response to Meghanaposs comments about him, regarding the infamous paparazzi pictures he staged with an agency before her wedding. The Duchess had, in an interview with Oprah, implied her dad had intentionally caused her pain with the photos. My first response is whataposs going to happen to these children  her dad said. I donapost know what terrible things are going to happen to these children because I did some photos, I donapost know what theyaposre talking about, what Harry is talking about, he kept saying apos you do that only one kid will be protectedapos, not two, I donapost know what heaposs talking about. Why am I being picked on  It seems Iaposm very easily picked on. title: womans horror after uber driver
story: Womans horror after Uber driver performed sex act then police didnt believe herThe woman has claimed she was trapped with a driver in a queue on the M when she felt the car “shaking” and heard a “rubbing noise” before she asked him “are you masturbating”An Uber spokesperson has said the drivers account has been suspended while an investigation takes place Image: PAByBeth Abbit:,  Nov A woman left horried after her Uber driver started “masterbating” while they were stuck in traffic is hitting out at police for allegedly saying her claim was “very doubtful”. The woman claims she was trapped with a driver in a queue on the M when she felt the car “shaking” and heard a “rubbing noise” before she asked him “are you masturbating”. The driver didn’t respond, she said. Feeling uncomfortable, she alleged she got out of the car to seek the help of a nearby police officer. But she says the officer told her he found her claim “very doubtful” and when she askedhe doubted her he simply ‘shrugged his shoulders’. The incident is now being investigated by Greater Manchester Police’s professional standards branch. The force has also apologised for “any instances whereby a member of the public has not received a good service from us”. Uber says they have suspended the driver’s account while an investigation takes place. The woman - who spoke to the Manchester Evening News and has not been named - requested an Uber to take her home from a work event in Manchester city centre just after pm on Thursday night last week.She was sitting in the back seat behind the driver, she said, when the car ground to a halt as they neared a police road closure around the site of an accident. So I was waiting in the taxi trying to chat to the driver and he was a bit grumpy. I put my rucksack on the seat next to me to rest my head,” she said. I noticed the car started shaking and I could hear this rubbing noise. I asked aposwhat are you doing apos. This went on and it stopped and started. I moved to the middle seat to try and distract him and tried to talk to him, asking how long he thought we would be here. I wanted him to stop. I text my husband and said aposIaposm fairly confident the driver of this Uber is masturbatingapos. He phoned me and said to put him on the phone but I didnapost want the driver to take my phone. There was a bit of this starting and stopping and the car shaking and the rubbing noise. I never actually saw his penis, buthe was not doing that he certainly wanted me to think he was. I said aposIaposm getting outapos and asked aposAre you masturbatingapos and he didnapost respond. The woman says she got out of the car onto the motorway and approached a nearby police officer. She explained the situation but was told she needed to get back inside her vehicle. He asked which car it was and started walking me back to the car, she says. I told him I wasnapost getting back in that taxi and he said aposyouaposre going to have to because you canapost stand out in the carriagewayapos. The woman says the officer then aposreluctantlyapos agreed to let her sit in the back of the police car. When she asked what their plan was she was told the officer could drop her at a shopping centre many miles from her home. She was there for around  minutes before anyone spoke to her properly, she says. Sometime later, she says another officer arrived and askedshe would like them to arrest the Uber driver. “I said ‘yeah’,” she says. “They askedI could identy him and I told them the name and car was on my Uber app. I told him what had happened and he told me this case was unlikely to get a prosecution. They had not even taken my name at that point. “By then I was more worried about how I would get home. I said ‘okay, leave it’. Then the first officer came over tomy phone and said ‘I find it very doubtful that a man would do this whilst he knows he’s trapped in the traffic’. “I said ‘are you telling me this didn’t happen’ and he just shrugged his shoulders and passed me the phone.” The woman says officers dropped her at McDonald’s, in Hattersley, where her husband had ordered her a cab home. She has since reported both the alleged crime and her complaint about officers’ conduct. They said there would be an investigation and I would get a written outcome,” she says. In my opinion that is quite a dangerous officer because he is not only inept and didnapost take a report, but he also tried to get me back in the taxi,” she added. From that driveraposs perspective heaposs seen me go to the police and seen them try to put me back in his car. If I had not been so insistent I could have ended back in that Uber. And someone  with perhaps less le experience might have. It was a sex crime. I was in a position where I was vulnerable, I told a police officer and you think they would at least get you home safe. A spokesperson for the Greater Manchester Police force said: Firstly, we completely acknowledge the effect incidents of this nature can have on victims, and we are sorry for any instances whereby a member of the public has not received a good service from us. Our job as police officers is to keep the public safe. We want all members of our community, especially women and girls, to feel they are not at risk of harm when going about their daily lives in Greater Manchester and we are working with partners across Greater Manchester to better achieve this. We can confirm that GMP has received a complaint regarding the police response to this incident which is in the process of being assessed by our Professional Standards Branch. “As a result it would be inappropriate for us to comment further at this time. An Uber spokesperson said: We are appalled by this allegation and have a zero tolerance policy on any such behaviour in the Uber community. “In this case the driveraposs account has been suspended while an investigation takes place.” Most ReadFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Greater Manchester PoliceAppsPolice carShopping centresCrime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: woman who found life endometriosis
story: Exclusive: Woman who found le with severe period pain not worth living calls for menstrual leaveLola Hall, , has called for menstrual leave to be introduced for all those suffering from severe period-related pain as she spoke of how the "stabbing pains" caused by her endometriosis made her want to quit her leLola Hall, , has called for menstrual leave to be introduced for people whose endometriosis is gravely debilitating Image: Lola HullByClaire Gilbody-DickersonNews reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA woman who contemplated quitting her le because of how much endometriosis was affecting her has called for menstrual leave policy to be introduced after she was demonised for calling sick. Lola Hall,  and from Camden, London, has been grappling with stabbing period pains ever since she had her first menstrual cycle aged . The pain persisted and got worse through adulthood, with it becoming so extreme at about the age of  that Lola felt like I didnapost want to be around anymore... Not because I wasn’t a valuable person or I hated myself but because I was in so much pain and my le was so heavily disrupted by the endometriosis that it didn’t feel like a le worth living.”Lola would at times have to ask her mother to help her while showeringbecause I couldn’t hold myself up long enough, while she would only have microwaved food as she didnapost trust herself with the stove because of the strong painkillers she was on, such as dihyrocodeine. My pain levels were at about  and the only reason they weren’t  is because I wasn’t blacked out most of the time, but I was screaming in pain on a daily basis, I was writhing in pain, the painkillers wouldn’t touch it.What are your thoughts on this  Let us know in the comments belowYet despite the searing pain, Lola, who is part of the Endometriosis UK support group in London, has in the past felt like she had no option but to go to work for fear of being penalised.Lola said her condition has in the past been perceived as a negative aspect of me or an inconvenience, and that has in turn had an impact on her mental health and performance. It become a sort of self-fulfilling prophecy. They demonise you and then you become more stressed, more likely to make mistakes and you become sicker from the stress. The -year-old was once also put under review, although she pointed out how her employers at the time werenapost aware her absence was due to her period. Lola said she felt her condition wouldnapost be seen as a real sickness. aposMiles behindapos Despite the UK being one of the most advanced countries in the world, its employment law still falls short of stipulating that women with premenstrual syndromecan take time off work. A survey of , UK women aged - from London-based company Yoppie found  per cent would support menstrual leave becoming a legal workplace requirement, compared to just six percent who were strongly against it. That while a total of  per cent said their workplace fell short of having any form of menstrual leave in place.Daniella Peri, the founder of Yoppie , said the UK is still miles behind countries like Indonesia, Zambia, parts of China, Japan, Taiwan, and South Korea, where menstrual leave is already legally enforced.Some will argue that our general sick leave policies are sufficient to cover menstrual leave, buta woman is having to take a day or two sick leave every month compared to the average of four or five sick days a year, employers may start to look unfavourably on them, Ms Peri said.  It’s this stigma that causes many to refrain from taking time off work when PMS hits in fear that they won’t be treated equally against their male counterparts. She added thatchange canapost happen via the government, they want to empower woman to campaign for the change in their own workplace sowe can start to make a change one company at a time.”aposI felt like an absolute corpseapos Lola had a laparoscopy two years ago and has now been put on a new medication which she calls a leline. But when her body was first adjusting to the treatment - an intake of hormones six times the typical dose - she felt like an absolute corpse and had to take three weeks of sick leave. She is grateful to have supportive employers who allowed her to do that, but realises they are the exception, not the rule.Explaining the extent to which the endometriosis can affect you, she said it can in some ways be compared to cancer because of how the cells behave and similar symptoms. A prostate chemotherapy drug which triggers a chemical menopause is also sometimes used to manage endometriosis, but the side effects are horrible.Backing calls for menstrual leave to be granted to employees affected by severe period-related symptoms, she said: “If you had a member of staff that had cancer or had diabetes - because diabetes affects the same amount of people that endometriosis does - they would be treated fairly at work. “But for some reason as soon as periods are brought into it, vaginas are brought into it, uteruses are brought into it, suddenly it’s no longer medical, suddenly it’s an icky woman’s issue we don’t talk about”. Endometriosis UK called on the government to urgently review how its policies on benefits and statutory sick pay are applied to those with endometriosis so they are not discriminated against due to having a condition linked to the menstrual cycle.” The charity, which supports , women across the country, told the Mirror: Endometriosis is not ‘just a bad period’. Those with the disease may have severe, debilitating pain. We don’t need generic menstrual leave we need employers, the Department of Work and Pensions and society to recognise endometriosis as a chronic condition and provide the support that they would to anyone with a chronic health condition. title: female construction manager says no
story: Female construction manager says no-one takes her seriously because of her looksTikTok user Autumn Westfall, who works in a construction company as a project manager in the US, says she was treated like a tea girl and her colleagues ignored her emailsAutumn Westfall is a project manager in commercial construction as well as a model Image: Autumn Westfall TikTokByTfany LoVideo News Reporter:,  Nov | commentsA woman has opened up about working as a construction manager in a male-dominated industry and being treated dferently because of her looks. Autumn Westfall says she was treated like a tea girl and her colleagues ignored her emails. Sharing her experiences on TikTok, the mum from from Macomb, Michigan, talked about pretty privilege and said it does exist.But while everyone assumes it gives you an advantage in le, there is apparently the opposite side of it too, the Daily Star reports.It is absolutely rude how when people find you attractive, they are generally just nice to you for that reason and that reason only, Autumn explains. Until you are in a power position who steps into a male-dominated industry and then you might as well be carrying around a tray of coffee and snacks. Autumn says in her case, she is often ignored by her co-workers because of the way she looks. She continued: Pretty privilege almost becomes the opposite in my experience. So the logicyou have nice hair, you have your makeup done, you have a nice outfit, you possibly couldnapost be in a power position or any intelligence whatsoever. For me I work in construction management on multi-million dollar jobs and I canapost tell you how fun it is to have my emails ignored, people literally talk to my male co-worker to act like Iaposm just there to serve them. Some people shared their similar experiences and said they were taken seriously when they went to work makeup-free. But Autumn said she get glammed up because it makes her happy, feel good and perform better. Getting my hair and makeup done makes me feel professional, it makes me feel aposI can get the job doneapos and thataposs what exactly Iaposm going to do, she added. I have two daughters and by the time they are choosing what career path they want go in, I want them to decide without worryingthey are going to be talked down to orthey are going to be treated professionally. I donapost want that to be an issue for them. doorbell camera filmed a apostriangular UFO apos flying over his home - and the footage shows a trio of lights moving slowly across the sky.Matt Doughty, , was watching TV with his friend Kevin Barritt last month when his phone pinged with a notication from his smart doorbell, warning something was outside his front door. He then played the captured footage and was amazed as he watched the eerie scene unfold, with an unidentied flying object gliding through the sky with three bright lights beaming through the darkness. Logistics manager Matt then called his aviation buff dad who checked an online flight tracker and claimed there was aposno plane trafficapos in the sky at all - leaving him to questionit could be extraterrestrial le. What do you think about Mattaposs sighting  Let us know in the comments...Matt, from St Albans, Hertfordshire, said: I was sat with my friend and said aposblimey, I didnapost hear the doorbell go but Iaposve got an alert come upapos. I looked at the footage and played it back. It was silent. Three lights came from the sky and I thought it was really weird. Where itaposs come through the trees, itaposs come over the house opposite me then the footage captures it coming from right to left. It disappears over the top of woodland to the left of my house.For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. It was a bit of a chilling feeling really - I thought aposoh my god, thataposs quite closeapos. I wonderedIaposd discovered something nobody knows anything about. title: mum left red faced after
story: Mum left red-faced after finding two frozen turkey dinosaurs in intimate actElyse McKenna, , had to do a double-take when she served her children dinner and saw two turkey dinosaurs locked in a passionate embrace - and she could only laugh when her kids asked about itElyse McKenna was left red-faced after finding two turkey dinosaurs locked in a passionate embrace Image: Kennedy News Elyse Nycky McKennaByJohn BettAudience Writer:,  Nov | comments A mum was left red-faced after finding two frozen turkey dinosaurs locked in an aposintimateapos act - and her children immediately asked what they were doing.Elyse McKenna, , was making dinner for her two kids, Trysten, , and five-year-old Ridley, when her partner Lee Faux fished the Bernard Matthews turkey dinosaurs out of the freezer. She said that two of them were locked in a passionate embrace and appeared to be having sex, and her two kids soon asked what the dinos were doing. Elyse told her kids that the turkey dinosaurs were just cuddling together to keep warm, and laughed off the potentially embarrassing incident. What do you think about the raunchy discovery  Let us know in the comments...The mum from Bideford, Devon, said: It looks like theyaposre having sex, when I saw them I had a bit of a giggle. I thought it was quite funny, I just thought aposmaybe theyaposre keeping warmapos . I said to my eldest aposmaybe they only put the two dinosaurs in there and thataposs how the rest of them turn up in the bagapos. My partner is quite deadpan, so he just came over and said aposlook at thisapos and said no more about it. I said aposquick grab a picture, we might be able to give people a giggleapos. Sadly it wasnapost a romance for the ages, as the pair ended up being cooked and eaten. Elyse said: These two ended up in the oven, unfortunately Lee did split them up before they went to the fiery heaven. I think they had quite a while in the freezer together to get to know each other first though. I might check the rest of the bag to check there are no more dinosaurs having fun in there.After sharing a picture of Lee clutching the duo on Facebook, captioned aposSo...The turkey dinosaurs seem to have been busy in the freezer…apos it went viral, racking up , likes and comments.Elyse said: Itaposs great to see people have been tagging their friends and wanting to share the fun. My first thought was to share it and give everyone a bit of a laugh because we could all do with cheering up these days. Social media users flooded the post with comments laughing at the turkey dinosaurs.  For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newslettershere. One wrote: Well, how  did everyone think Turkey dinosaurs were made ! Another commented: Wellsomeone put me in the freezer I’d be doing whatever I could to keep warm too! One wrote: and that is how more turkey dinosaurs are made. Bernard Matthews have been contacted for comment.Do you have a story to share  Weaposd love to hear all about it. news weird-news my-date-only-bought-food-"Date refuses to buy woman food because she had no cashByRosaleen FentonAudience Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments When it comes to personal relationships, itaposs healthy to set expectations and boundaries.And while the apps can be useful for helping you meet a wide range of people, itaposs only when you meet in person that you knowyou have a personal connection or not. We all certain things weaposre looking for from a partner - and values we want them to uphold. They might be political or personal - with many Brits vowing to never date someone with opposing political views. But one woman sparked a debate on social media after revealing that her date didnapost cover her meal after she forgot to bring cash - and askedshe should see him again.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here In a viral TikTok, she explained in subtitles that this was their first date and that she had asked him out. One woman commented: If he asked you out, then he should be buying. If you asked him out, it would be on you. You asking is a huge red flag. Another wrote: I personally offer to pay on the first date but knowing your date came expecting a freebie...should he go out again is the question. You should always have money for emergencies, whathe left you there  asked another.
