title: crisp packets recycled for survival blankets
story: Updated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowPupils at Lochgilphead High School are putting their snacking to good use, helping out a homeless charity and keeping rubbish out of landfill.Head boy Archie MacColl-Smith, head girl Brie Pennell and their fellow pupils have been collecting empty crisp packets for a project that turns them into insulating blankets for homeless people.The Iron Man Survival charity is run by Miley Porritt who has combined his ironing business with his experience of sleeping rough to create these le-saving blankets.While it takes  years for a crisp packet to decompose  of them can be ironed together and turned into a survival blanket for a homeless person to keep their sleeping bag dry and insulated.Head boy Archie MacColl-Smith said: #I have set up a station at school where used crisp packets can be left.#I wash them and then we will send them down to Somerset where they get ironed together into insulated blankets for the homeless and will get handed out over the festive period.#The charity has been delighted with the response its appeal has had across the country from collectors like those in Lochgilphead.Miley said: #The people involved in this project really are amazing so selfless and devoted.#Thank you to everyone for all the energy you have given to this worthy cause. I hope you all know the priceless impact you have had on so many lives.#

title: tayvallich group joins musical call for action
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.Subscribe NowColin CameronA tidal wave of music crashed on to the shores of the River Clyde and COP earlier this week # an anthem for action on climate change.Among hundreds of music makers from around the globe making their presence felt was a group of people from Mid Argyll.The idea was born early in . As COP was originally to be held in November that year, a small group of Scottish artists planned to use the power of music in a live performance to promote global wellbeing and climate justice.With pilot funding from Creative Scotland, community music group Oi Musica, specialising in street band music, joined forces with the all-inclusive Soundhouse Choir and award-winning folk musician Karine Polwart.As inspiration, Karine drew on the mythology of Saint Mungo and Glasgow#s famous #the tree, the bird, the fish and the bell#.The song Enough is Enough was born.As the pandemic took hold and the conference was postponed, plans changed. The piece became a music video, and the idea to invite many more people to add their voice took shape.An invitation was put out to community groups to record their own version of the song to increase pressure on leaders to make decisive action at COP .Described as #a crashing, tumbling outpouring of music that starts with a few small drops, gathering pace and momentum as more people join, and building to a climax# the full force was unleashed at .pm on Wednesday November  in Govan with a mass performance as part of COP .At Govan was Tayvallich-based musician Sarah Phizacklea # but on the Saturday before travelling to Glasgow Sarah invited a group of people from Tayvallich, Carsaig and Crinan to her barn to create their version of Enough is Enough.Sarah explained: #It felt wonderful to add some weight to such an important cause, a bit more pressure on our leaders to actually commit to tackling climate change. And it was so much fun!#Our video has been uploaded to the growing collection of voices from all over the country and globally.#There were about  of us in total. It was filmed by Mark and Jane Smith, James Lehmann did the sound recording and the singers were Mary McNeill, Iona Barr, Kathie Baer, Kathie Fe, Jan Aksnes, Charlie Silverton, Ulla Hammervig, Fiona Lowrie, Biddy Simpson, Mary McLauchlan and Val Beattie.The band were Nils Aksnes, Keira Anderson, Kevin Williams and Hugh Fe. Nicholas Mes of the Tavallich shop fed us a fabulous warming stew.#She added: #I know the people who wrote it and thought the idea of everyone singing the same song with the same message was so powerful and gave a feeling of hope, that together we can solve the climate crisis.#The group#s video can be seen on Facebook or on Vimeo vimeo #. Check out letitgrow.scot for more information on the wider project.Search #MusicforCOP to find all the videos.

title: peeblesshire-woman-ran-marathon-memory-beautiful-mum
story: A BORDERS woman completed the London Marathon in memory of her "beautul mum" who passed away following a battle with cancer.Fiona Kennedy, from Peebles, ran her first marathon in  to mark her mother completing  years of treatment for soft tissue cancer and to raise money for Sarcoma UK ndash the charity which had supported her mum throughout her treatment.After completing the Edinburgh race in May  and raising pound,, Fionas mum passed away at the age of  in September ."Mumrsquos ethos meant that she took the years of surgery, chemotherapy, radiotherapy, and drug trials in her stride," said Fiona. "She continued to travel, play an active part in her grandchildrenrsquos lives and was a much-loved we, mum, sister, and aunt.":Feast of live rugby available for fans in the Borders this weekendAlthough shed sworn to never run again, Fiona, her aunt, uncle and cousins agreed to run a marathon in her mums memory.The family promptly signed up to run the London Marathon  for Sarcoma UK.However, the coronavirus pandemic meant last years marathon was postponed.But despite lockdown, Fiona continued to train for when the marathon was rearranged for October this year.:Man threatened to kill his partner during a bust-up in the Borders"I swore I would never run again after Edinburgh and I crossed the line in London two years later having raised a further pound, for Sarcoma UK," said Fiona."I have been out running in my finishers t-shirt twice since completing London, and I have felt a real sense of accomplishment pounding the pavements in that prestigious t-shirt."Crossing the finish line was a huge sense of relief."My cousin Lucy and I crossed it together hand in hand and promptly burst into tears."The sense of achievement was felt immediately, not least because the staff, marshals and volunteers were amazing in their support and care."The congratulations came from runners, supports and strangers..remove"Mum wasnrsquot at the finish line in London but Irsquom sure she would have been amazed and proud in equal measures.":Photo Gallery: Some of the best Halloween costumes from across the BordersFiona is now looking forward to ing to sports she enjoys, but can also see herself joining in park runs.She said: "I am looking forward to ing to other forms of exercise that I love, but I do see myself factoring in the odd Parkrun to tick my legs over."In terms of fundraising ndash I will have a lelong affiliation with Sarcoma UK."Mum wanted to do more in terms of contributing to research, raising awareness and rising funds, and this is a duty I have inherited."I will continue to look for ways to support the charity I have such fondness for."

title: scott-brash-statue-plans-monument-add-new-dimension
story: THE Olympic legacy of Scott Brash, which was honoured with the erection of a statue, could soon be illuminated with a golden glow.The showjumper landed back in Peebles to unveil the lesize sculpture in recognition of his gold medal back in .The tribute to one of the regionrsquos greatest ever sportsmen was warmly welcomed by the community, and is a spectacular vision on entry to the town from Edinburgh Road.The project was the brainwave of voluntary group Bonnie Peebles, which commissioned the sculpture, which artist Kevin Paxon designed and created from recycled horseshoes.Now, community leaders would like to highlight his golden glory further and hope to work with Bonnie Peebles to clear the final hurdle in this project.During a meeting of Peebles Community Council, members discussed installing lighting at the monument. It was suggested that solar-powered lights would be the most cost-effective option.Tweeddale East councillor Robin Tatler said an application to fund the lighting could be submitted to the Peebles Parking Fees Fund.Chairman Les Turnbull said: ldquoThe Scott Brash monument is a wonderfully impressive artwork at the gateway to the town.ldquoTo have it lit would add another dimension for us all to enjoy, particularly as the nights draw in.

title: scots-women-take-japan-dam-health-stadium-sunday
story: BORDERS trio Lana Skeldon, Lisa Thomson and Chloe Rollie have been named in Scotland Women Head Coach Bryan Eassonrsquos -player squad for the upcoming Autumn Test against Japan at the DAM Health Stadiumndash live on BBC ALBA.If they play Skeldon will collect her th cap, Thomson will pick up her th cap Rollie will get her th cap.Easson said: ldquoThe upcoming Autumn Test against Japan is a great opportunity for us to learn from our experience in the Rugby World Cup  Europe Qualiers.ldquoJapan have recently qualied for the Rugby World Cup as the highest ranked team in the Asia qualication process so this will be an ideal test for us as it exposes us to a dferent opponent and playing style ahead of our final qualication tournament next year."The players are also excited to run out in front of a home crowd for the first time since , especially as theyve played mostly behind closed doors for the past  months. Weve all hugely missed having crowds so itll be fantastic to have supporters along at the DAM Health Stadium to cheer the players on."Scotlandrsquos last encounter against the Brave Blossoms was in November , which was also the last match they played in front of a home crowd, with Japan taking the spoils that day with a - win.Eassonrsquos squad recently kept their World Cup ambitions in sight following two back-to-back wins against Spain and Ireland during the Rugby World Cup  Europe Qualiers in Parma.The sidersquos recent success has also seen them rise to an all-time high of ninth in the Womenrsquos World Rugby rankings.Forwards: Leah Bartlett , Christine Belisle , Sarah Bonar , Lisa Cockburn , Evie Gallagher , Jade Konkel , Rachel Malcolm , Rachel McLachlan , Louise McMillan , Lyndsay OrsquoDonnell , Lana Skeldon , Emma Wassell , Molly Wright , Anne Young .removeBacks: Shona Campbell , Megan Gaffney , Sarah Law , Rhona Lloyd , Jenny Maxwell , Holly McIntyre , Helen Nelson , Chloe Rollie , Hannah Smith , Meryl Smith , Lisa ThomsonEvie Wills Tickets for Scotland Women v Japan Women are on sale via the SRU website.Kids for pound tickets are available with a paying adult, at pound, and Us go for pound.

title: exciting-competition-young-artists-borders
story: BUDDING young artists in the Borders will have the chance to reimagine the facade of Kelso Town Hall.The best designs will be projected onto the building, for two spectacular nights in February between Saturday th and Saturday th, alongside artwork from Borders Art Fair participating artists.A selection of the designs will also be exhibited at the Borders Art Fair in March.This competition is open to all young people, up to, and including, the age of , who live or, go to school in, the Scottish Borders.There will be prizes for the best entries, according to age groups: under s, -s and  years and over.Digital designs should be sent to info@bordersartfairDesigns on paper can be posted to Border Arts Development, Kirkmains Farm, Jedburgh TD TP or scanned and emailed to info@bordersartfair.Moving image designs should be no longer than  secondsPlease include your name, age, address, email address or phone numberApplicants under  must get consent from their parent or legalbefore entering the competition. This competition is free to enter and no purchase is necessaryBorder Arts Development C.I.C. must receive entries by .pm on Monday th December .A template is available as a starting point for and can be downloaded via https:www.bordersartfair

title: borders-recorded-50-coronavirus-cases-24-hours
story: THE Borders has recorded  new cases of coronavirusin the last day, latest figures show.According to Scottish Government data published at pm today , the Borders has now seen , cases of the virus since the start of the pandemic.There remain  people in the hospital in the Borders with confirmed cases of the virus.Scotland has now recorded , cases of the virus since March last year, according to the latest data.

title: galashiels-christmas-tree-height-revealed-meeting
story: THE Christmas tree in Galashiels will be shorter than usual this year, a meeting has heard.Galashiels representative Euan Jardine, of the Conservatives, said that Scottish Borders Council was unable to source a ft tree for the town.At a meeting of the community council, Mr Jardine said: ldquoThe Christmas tree is to be delivered and put in place within the next two weeks.:Coronavirus: NHS Borders issues warning amid lsquorisingrsquo number of cases in regionldquoUnfortunately itrsquos not going to be ft, itrsquos going to be ft.ldquoI know some people wonrsquot be happy with that but unfortunately they just couldnrsquot source one.It will be the third consecutive year that a ft Christmas tree will stand in Galashiels.There will be no improvement to the lights in Galashiels this year, or an official switch-on.

title: borders-projects-secure-funding-worth-1-3m-uk-government
story: EIGHT projects across the Borders have secured funding totalling pound. million.Scottish Borders Councilidentied  applications ndash with five unsuccessful and one bid pending a decision.The projects granted funding must be delivered by a deadline of June , .They are:pound, to support the development of environmentally focused courses in entrepreneurship and carbon literacy at Borders Collegepound, to fund an employment and wellbeing programme for people living in housing associations. The Berwickshire Housing programme will deliver digital skills, financial literacy, and promote good mental healthpound, to develop the electric vehicle charging infrastructurepound, for the Scottish Borders Community Development Companyfor workshops to help communities deliver larger scale projectspound, to help the development of a mountain biking centre in Tweeddalepound, for a feasibility study to develop an area of land purchased by Newcastleton and District Community Trustpound, to help support the delivery of training and heritage focused activities by Archaeology Scotlandpound, for the Southern Uplands Partnership to develop energy efficiency training schemesThe money is part of a pound million UK Government funding pot ldquodesigned to support communities to pilot new ideas and approaches to better support people in need.SBC was asked for information about the unsuccessful bids and the project waiting on a decision, but did not supply any details before this newspaper went to press.Council leader Shona Haslam said: ldquoLarge scale projects that are driven by people who live in our communities and are passionate about making the Scottish Borders a better place to live and work can make a real dference to the lives of many.ldquoThe support provided by the UK Governmentrsquos Community Renewal Fund is vital to helping innovative and locally-led projects breathe new le into towns and villages across the Borders and help support the regions recovery from COVID-..removeThe Conservative Tweeddale East councillor added: ldquoWhilst it is great news that eight projects have been successful in securing funding, we will be working closely with those unsuccessful applicants to identy alternative means of taking forward their projects.Conservative Mid Berwickshire councillor Mark Rowley, SBCrsquos executive member for economic regeneration and finance, described the money as a ldquomajor boost to our region.ldquoThe amount of money granted to these inidual projects reflects the strength of their applications and their potential to improve the lives of Borderers by delivering jobs and improving local communities.ldquoItrsquos welcome news to see the timescale for delivery of these projects being extended after a delay to the announcement of funding. This will give much needed additional time to allow our projects to be delivered to their full potential and provide maximum benefit to the Scottish Borders.

title: borders-buses-remembrance-day-closure-affect-services
story: BORDERS Buses has warned passengers that a number of services will be affected by a ldquoRemembrance Day closure.Berwickrsquos Castlegate will be shut between .am and pm for the Festival of Remembrance, according to the travel company.Borders Buses has issued an apology to impacted customers, adding that it is ldquoout of our control.The services set to be affected are:The am from Galashiels will terminate at Berwick Railway StationThe .am from Tweedmouth Retail Park will start from Berwick Railway Station at .amThe .am service from Kelso to Berwick will be unable to serve Golden Square and will ert from the Catholic school to Berwick Railway StationBThe B will ert via Castle Terrace, A, A to the Catholic school. During the closure Borders Buses says it will be unable to serve Castlegate and Golden SquareThe .am service from St Abbs will terminate at Berwick Railway StationThe . service to St Abbs will leave from the railway station

title: half-price-tickets-now-available-see-tapestry
story: THE GREAT Tapestry of Scotland has been awarded Visit Scotlandrsquos Days Out Incentive Fund.The Tapestry tells the inspirational true story of the countryrsquos history, heritage and culture . It was hand stitched by over  people in communities across Scotland and transported by land, sea and air to come together.It is made up of   and  miles of wool .The visitor centre in Galashiels will now be offering half price day tickets from Monday  November  until  February .During this special offer adult tickets will be pound., concession tickets pound., child ticket pound., Burns family ticket  tickets at pound per ticket, Inglis family ticket  tickets at pound. per ticket.Half-price tickets can be purchased online at: www.greattapestryofscotland or in the centre from Monday  November.

title: borders-activists-mark-cop26-weekend-events
story: ALTHOUGH a great number of activists flocked to COP in Glasgow this weekend, environmentalists in the Borders also shone a spotlight on climate issues here.Supporters of the Fridays For Future campaign joined the weekly silent vigil in Melrose in solidarity with the Fridays For Future march which took place in Glasgow, led by Greta Thunberg.As well as the silent vigil, climate activists in the Borders also took part in a series of events over the weekend, including the Great Borders River Clean and the Borders Book Festival.ldquoTheyrsquore all lsquoclimate beaconsrsquo showing we care for the future of the planet, said Greener Melrose chairman Donald McPhillimy of the weekendrsquos events.ldquoWe feel itrsquos good to celebrate this, while COP is happening, so wersquove launched an appeal for groups, organisations, businesses, organic producers etc in the Borders to send us details about their green activities, and how others can get involved.:I know some people wont be happy: Height of Gala Christmas tree revealedOn Saturday, Greener Melrose met with cyclists who had been loaned Ebikes as part of Ebikes for Borderers ndash a scheme to help people seethey would be a suitable replacement to their car for work or leisure purposes.And over the course of the weekend volunteers across the region joined the Great Borders River Clean, helping to collect rubbish and debris from river banks.Volunteers from Greener Melrose were also at the Borders Book Festival recently with a display of their activities and promoting their map of eco-friendly actions being taken around the Borders. This tied in with talks at the festival from Tom Heap who discussed his new book  Ways to Save the Planet and a presentation from journalist Robert Peston about his experiences at COP.A lsquoGreen Beacons of Hopersquo list is being produced in the Borders to highlight what actions are being taken locally to help tackle the climate crisis, to highlight the green activities people can join in with..removeMr McPhillimy said: ldquoJoining with others, to do something positive, is a great start to helping communities be resilient to the effects of climate change, and it feels good to be working with nature, helping restore decades of damage. It certainly beats feeling anxious and helpless in the midst of all the dire warnings wersquore no longer able to ignore. The first step can be to check out whatrsquos already happening.:Services to be affected by lsquoRemembrance Day closurersquo, says Borders BusesGreen activities being included range from growing your own fruits and vegetables to upcycling old clothes and household items.For more information about Greener Melrose activities, the green map and Beacons of Hope listing, contact greenermelrose@live

title: updated-book-commemoration-remembers-gala-woman
story: THE ONLY woman from Galashiels who died during active service in World War II was remembered recently with the publication of the revised edition of the townrsquos Book of Commemoration.Fay T. Currie, an aircraftwomen nd class, WAAF, was only  years old when she lost her le on the th September , following an illness while serving her country. She passed away at Bridge of Larne and is interred at Galashiels Eastlands Cemetery.Gordon Keddie, a volunteer researcher said: ldquoOur group felt it was important those who lost their lives in WWII should be remembered in the same way as was done with those from WWI in , when the book was published.The Book of Commemoration, which lists the iniduals from the town who gave their lives in both World Wars, was produced by Energise Galashiels Trust and has been updated recently following a yearlong project when a group of volunteers researched each of the  men and one woman fallen from World War II, including poignant photos of the townsfolk.The Book of Commemoration is a legacy to Gala Remembers, the extensive programme of activities that took place in  to commemorate the th anniversary of the end of World War I.Debbie Paterson, EGT committee member, added: ldquoWhile the work of Energise Galashiels Trust is often future-focused, it is important that we reflect back in time too, especially when remembering the people of the town who made the ultimate sacrice by giving their lives to ensure we today enjoy our freedoms. We are honoured to be able to continue to support the Book of Commemoration this year with the addition of more detail and images of the WWII fallen.Energise Galashiels Trust would like to thank Jenner McLaughlin, Hazel Hunter, Tommy Turnbull, and Gordon Keddie for their tireless work that resulted in the comprehensive revision of the Book.

title: galashiels-20mph-speed-limit-set-reversed-roads
story: THE mph speed limit on some Galashiels roads will be removed, a councillor has revealed.Scottish Borders Council introduced the controversial restrictions in October  as part of a trial under its Spaces for People scheme.At a meeting of the community council on Wednesday , Galashiels representative Harry Scott announced that some ldquorevisions are set to go ahead.ldquoTherersquos been some criticism and some love of them [the limits] but the plan at the moment is for a revision, the independent councillor said.:Gala remembers only woman from town to die on active service in WWAccording to Mr Scott, the mph limit will be reinstated ldquoon the road leading to the recycling centre past Melrose Gait and Coopersknowe.A ldquobuffer zone of mph will also be placed from the town boundary on Melrose Road to near the junction with Hawthorn Road, with new mph signage to be erected from that point to indicate the change in limit.Winston Road will also have its mph limit reinstated down to the roundabout with Galafoot, says Mr Scott.He confirmed that the mph limit will stay on Wood Street, as well as on ldquoall the residential schemes in the town.Member of the public Richard Lees said that ldquoa lot of people have universal disapproval of these mph limits on social media, and asked Mr Scottthe council has a way of measuring the advantages of the scheme.:Borders man encouraged young girl to engage in sexual activity, court hearsResponding, Mr Scott said: ldquoIrsquom not an expert but I do knowa child is struck at mph they have got a  per cent more chance of surviving thantheyrsquore struck at mph.ldquoThere have been some concerns about an increase in pollution but Irsquom reliably told that a car travelling at mph in the proper gear exerts less pollution than one travelling at mph.ldquoMy information is that the mph limit is overall a good thing. I do share with you some reservations about whether mph is really a requirement for a lsquothrough roadrsquo in a town but I think what is being proposed by the officer is reasonable and I certainly donrsquot have any objection to it..removeThe mph speed restrictions are part of an -month council trial covering  towns and villages in the Borders.The aim of the scheme is to make it easier for people to safely walk and cycle during everyday journeys.:I know some people wont be happy: Height of Gala Christmas tree revealedChanges to the restrictions were also announced at a meeting of Selkirk Community Council meeting on Monday .On the A into Selkirk from Galashiels the mph is to be reinstated up to Viewfield Park, then mph through the town thereafter.A mph limit on the A from Hawick will also be reinstated ndash however police and road safety officers have yet to decide where.

title: westruther-woman-admits-drink-driving-offence-weekend
story: A BORDERS woman appeared from custody at Jedburgh Sherf Court on Monday and admitted a drink-driving offence at the weekend while already disqualied.Fty-one-year-old Joyce Barrett, of Westruther, also pleaded guilty to having no insurance.Sentence was deferred until next month for the production of background reports and she was released on bail.You might also be interested in:mph speed limit set to be reversed on Galashiels roads, meeting hearsBorders man encouraged young girl to engage in sexual activity, court hearsDog fouling in the Borders is getting worse and worse, says Gala councillor

title: 3-000-half-price-tickets-available-abbotsford-house
story: VISITORS can explore Sir Walter Scotts beautul Scottish Borders home at Abbotsford for half price thanks to a limited offer as part of the Visit Scotlands Great Days Out in Scotland scheme.There are nearly , half-price tickets to claim, and the offer includes entry to the House, Chapel and Gardens.It also includes half price entry to Christmas  in the historic house, which opens on December th.This magical Christmas experience will allow visitors to explore the house as it might have been for Christmas in Scotts day including a special edition Christmas audio guide.Giles Ingram, Abbotsfordrsquos Chief Executive said: ldquoLast year we extended the season for the first time in seven years, and wersquove decided to do the same again in Scottrsquos th anniversary year, making the event even bigger and better!ldquoWersquore delighted that for the first time ever Father Christmas will be on site to meet local children and our Christmas Market will now be over two weekends in November. The historic house will be open for longer, decorated for the celebrations and telling the story of a special festive season for Scott, when he celebrated the completion of his wonderful home.ldquoAlthough  hasnrsquot been as dficult as , we have missed our international and group visits, which were an important part of our income. Thankfully we have continued to welcome visitors from across the UK and our local market has been very supportive, especially helping us to celebrate Scottrsquos th birthday at Scottfest  in August. Wersquore now inviting them to come again and celebrate a very special Christmas with us.The celebrations at Abbotsford begin with a Christmas Market over the last two weekends in November, featuring local crafters and suppliers. The Markets will run from .am ndash pmon Saturday and Sunday, th  st and th  th November. Christmas wreath making workshops are running on Friday th November..removeThe historic house will close as usual on Tuesday November th and then re-open on Saturday th December, beautully decorated with foliage from the estate and with a unique literary inspired Christmas tree in Scottrsquos magnicent Library.Also on Saturday th December, Father Christmas will arrive at Abbotsford for the first time. Local children can meet him and his Elves in his festive grotto every Friday, Saturday and Sunday until th December.A Christmas shopping evening will be held in the Abbotsford gt shop on Thursday nd December where visitors can find unique presents, including a range of exclusive items created to celebrate the th anniversary of Sir Walter Scott, including Abbotsford gin  whisky.Ochiltreersquos cafeacute will also remain open throughout December for visitors to enjoy their Christmas menu and festive treats. The gt shop and cafeacute are open seven days a week, am-pm, until rd December and am-pm on Christmas Eve. They are also open thndash th Dec, am-pm, and st Dec, am-pm.Visitors should check the opening dates and times before visiting.Full details of dates, times and tickets for events are on Abbotsfordrsquos web site: scottsabbotsford

title: bright-side-life-hailed-huge-success
story: THE BRIGHT Side of Le benefit show which lit up the Eastgate Theatre last month has been hailed a huge success and could potentially become an annual event.Local community drama group Tweed Theatre brought together, over two nights on nd and rd October, a slew of talented local performers to celebrate the resurgence of performing arts.Tweed Theatre itself, along with the Downright Homespun Radio Company, Sara Bolesrsquo Stride Young Dancers and Eastgate Follies, Shakespeare at Traquair and Celtic Beat with Joe Wilton, collaborated in a production lasting a little over an hour which showcased the cream of local talent in a fabulously upbeat celebration of live drama, comedy, music and dance.The eveningrsquos entertainment involved hysterically funny satirical sketches from DHRC, superb dancing from Sara Bolesrsquo young and mature artists, a scintillating  minute Hamlet from Shakespeare at Traquair, two classic excerpts from Tweed Theatre-one from an Alan Bennett monologue and the other Mrs Culfeatherrsquos mince from The Steamie, and all rounded off by Nomad Beatrsquos sensational Celtic Beat grouprsquos foot-tapping music.The finale saw the audience joyfully joining in two verses of the immortal Monty Pythonrsquos Always Look on the Bright Side of Le, the song after which the show was named.The production was so successful, raising a considerable amount for the Eastgate Theatre, sending people home happy on both nights and encouraging local performers to collaborate creatively, that there is a feeling amongst the performers that the iety benefit show could become a regular event. Watch this space!Organisers wish to thank the ferociously talented artists who came together and say that it was worth the six months of planning to see the audience spilling into the street entertained and looking forward to what we all hope will be a completeto enjoying the thrill of live performance.

title: club-international-rugby-fans-oval-ball
story: Itrsquos a diluted card of club rugby for supporters in the Borders this weekend but a few exciting games are still taking place.Tonightthere will be a Borders derby in the Premiership when Jed-Forest host Selkirk.In National League Division One Melrose have an away fixture against the Stirling Wolves.In East League Division One Duns have a home game against Haddington and Hawick Force play Hawick Linden in a friendly at Mansfield Park.Tomorrow Gregor Townsend on-form Scotland side face world champions South Africa at BT Murrayfield.In the National League Division one Biggar travel to face Ayr and in National League Division Three Berwick are away to Strathmore.In East League Three Gala YM host Lasswade.In Reserve League East One Biggar A host Jed-forest A whilst on Reserve League East Two Gala A host Lasswade and Kelso Sharks take on Watsonians at Poynder Park.In the Semi-Junior Borders League Jed Thistle face Hawick Youth, Kelso Harlequins meet Gala Wanderers, Melrose Wasps host Duns Colts, Peebles Colts are at home to Carlisle Colts and Selkirk Youth host Morpeth Colts.On Sunday Kelso Ladies host Broughton.In Edinburgh Scotland Women face Japan at the Dam Health Stadium.Kick off times y so always check before going along to the games.

title: a7-driver-overturned-lorry-taken-bgh-serious-injury
story: THE driver of an overturned lorry has been taken to Borders General Hospital with a ldquoserious injury, say police.Officers say they were called to reports of the vehicle on the A near Crude Hill in the early hours of Friday morning .The driver, in his twenties, was taken to hospital.:mph speed limit set to be reversed on Galashiels roads, meeting hearsThe road has been closed to recover the vehicle, according to police.A Police Scotland spokesperson said: ldquoPolice were called to the A near Crude Hill around .am on Friday,  November, following a report of an overturned artic lorry.ldquoThe driver, in his twenties, was taken to Borders General Hospital with a serious injury.ldquoThe road has been closed to facilitate recovery of the vehicle and officers continue to liaise with the relevant partner agencies.

title: shona-haslam-scottish-borders-council-leader-step
story: SHONA HASLAM is stepping down as leader of Scottish Borders Council, it has been announced.The Conservative councillor for Tweeddale East was appointed as head of the council in .But she is now set to step away from the role to lead a new think tank ldquothat focuses on how we build a stronger community in Scotland for the future.She will remain an elected member for Tweeddale East until the local government election in May next year.Elected members will choose a new leader at the full council meeting on November .Mrs Haslam said: "It has been an honour and a privilege to serve as council leader over the last four years. We have achieved so much including the Borderlands Inclusive Growth Deal, the launch of South of Scotland Enterprise, destination play parks, and iPads to all of our learners through the award winning Inspire Learning programme.ldquoIt has not been an easy four years either with serious floods in our towns, a fire at Peebles High School and of course COVID-. Our communities have joined forces and pulled together in all of these challenges and to see how this has happened has been one of the best things about this role.ldquoI am not leaving the public sector, or politics, and will be leading a new think tank in Scotland that focuses on how we build a stronger community in Scotland for the future.ldquoI am excited about the future and the opportunities it holds and know that the Scottish Borders is going to continue to grow from strength to strength.Council convener David Parker said: "I would like to thank Shona for her work as leader over the past four years and congratulate her on all she has achieved. She has made an enormous contribution to the Scottish Borders.ldquoThe focus she has placed on mental health and the huge amount of work she carried out on Inspire Learning in our schools are just two of the things I think she deserves great credit for.ldquoAs the first female leader of this council she will have a special place in its history..removeldquoI look forward to welcoming and working with the new leader after the council meeting later this month."

title: a7-closure-borders-buses-suspends-x95-services-rest-day
story: BORDERS Buses has suspended X services between Hawick and Carlisle due to a closure on the A.Police were called to reports of an overturned lorryat around .am today , with officers closing the road to recover the vehicle.And Borders Buses says it has taken the ldquohard decision to stop all remaining X services for the remainder of the day due to the closure.A spokesperson for the travel company said: ldquoWe have been informed that the A closure is expected to remain in place for most of the day.ldquoAs this closure is out with our control, we have taken the hard decision to suspend all remaining X services between Hawick and Carlisle for the remainder of today.:Shona Haslam to step down as leader of Scottish Borders CouncilIt is the companyrsquos intention toto normal tomorrow, but this is ldquoonly an optionthe road reopens.According to Traffic Scotland, the A is now running under temporary traffic lights at Canonbie following the overnight incident.Meanwhile, police have confirmed that a crash took place in Stow last night.There were no injuries, according to officers.A Police Scotland spokesperson said: ldquoWe received a report of a road traffic crash involving a car and a lorry on the A Galashiels Road in Stow around .pm on Thursday, November , .ldquoThere were no injuries reported and vehicle recovery was arranged.

title: selkirk-invited-take-part-canadian-christmas-festival
story: SOUTERS are once again invited to take part in an international Christmas event with other towns and cities named Selkirk.Last year the town was invited to join the Holiday Alley festival held in the city of Selkirk in Manitoba, Canada, which was forced online due to the coronavirus pandemic.As part of the festival in , Selkirk communities around the world were invited to film themselves singing and dancing to a version of the  Days of Christmas. However, this year those wanting to get involved will be singing and dancing along to Dance in the Street, Again ndash written by Selkirk, Manitoba, artist Brenton Thorvaldson and based on the original song Dancing In The Street by Martha and the Vandellas.Organisers of Holiday Alley have also prepared choreography for Souters to follow or you can create your own moves.All the submitted videos will then be edited together in the lsquoWorldwide Dancing in the Street Videorsquo that will air on Holiday Alley web-TV on Tuesday, November . Anyone wishing to take part in this yearrsquos video, should submit their contributions to the Holiday Alley team by November . Visit: forms.gle NDfzbEshVpsEMJ

title: one-four-double-jabbed-people-uk-likely-received-extra-dose
story: One in four of all double-jabbed people in the UK are likely to have received either a booster or third dose of Covid- vaccine, new figures suggest.A total of ,, extra doses of vaccine have now been delivered across the country, according to Government data.This is the equivalent of .% of everyone in the UK who has previously received a first and second dose.Not all double-jabbed people are currently eligible for an extra dose.Boosters are available six months after a second dose for all adults aged  and over, along with other key groups including frontline health and social care workers, while third doses are available eight weeks after a second dose to people aged  and over with severely weakened immune systems.vw,vw,px, px"But the latest figures reflect the scale of the rollout of extra jabs, as well as the speed at which it is being delivered.A week ago, the total number of extra doses stood at just over nine million, or the equivalent of one in five of all double-jabbed people.That figure now stands at one in four.Analysis by the PA news agency shows Scotland has given an extra dose of vaccine to the equivalent of .% of its double-jabbed population, ahead of Wales , Englandand Northern Ireland .Scotland and Wales both publish daily figures for vaccine take-up by entire age groups ndash whether they are double-jabbed or not ndash and these show .% of all people aged  and over in Scotland have now received an extra dose, along with .% in Wales.In England, . million over-s have now had an extra dose ndash the equivalent of around % of all people in this age group, based on the latest population estimates.Some , over-s in Northern Ireland have received an extra dose, or around %..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: One in four double-jabbed people in UK likely to have received extra dose

title: put-christmas-tree
story: It may only be November, but people are already preparing for Christmas and maybe even thinking about putting up the tree.The date for putting up the Christmas tree tends to y from family to family, with some opting for an early start to the festivities, while others wait right until the last minute.But did you know theres a traditional date for putting up your tree Heres everything you need to know about when you should be putting up your Christmas tree...When should Iput my Christmas tree up According to tradition in the UK, you should put your Christmas tree up around the beginning of advent, which is four Sundays before Christmas.This year, advent will start on November , however lots of people will choose to wait until December .Roman Catholic tradition on the other hand is at the other end of the spectrum - waiting until Christmas eve to put up the tree.The Queen finishes "dressing" her tree on Christmas eve, with all the members of the Royal family joining in as a festive family activity.While there are dferent traditions, it is of course completely up to you when you choose to put up your tree and start celebrating the festive season!What date should I take my Christmas tree down Again, according to tradition, you should take your tree down on the th day of Christmas, which is January .The first day of Christmas is unsurprisinglyDecember  and traditionally is followed by  further days of celebration.January  marks the beginning of the Christian holiday Epiphany.Superstition suggests it is "bad luck" to keep your decorationsup after this date.However last year many people around the country kept their Christmas lights up well into February to maintain some festive cheer during the post-Christmaslockdown.

title: scotland-v-moldova-channel-kick-off-time-watch-live-tv-tonight
story: Scotlandwill play Moldova tonight in the World Cup Qualiers marking their penultimate Group F match.Steve Clarkes side currently sit in second place with  points trailing Denmarkwho lead with  points.The top two teams from each group will qualy for the play-offs for the  Quatar WorldCup anda win tonight will secure Scotlands second place finish.The pressure may be on, but Scotland can come into the match with confidence having won - against Moldova in September.Of course, that match was slightly closer than anticipated and took place in front of a home crowd whereas tonights match is at Zimbru stadium in Moldova.Regardless, Scotland will look to close the deal to take them once step closer to the World Cup dream.Heres what you need to know about tonights match and how you can tune in...What time is kick-off for Scotland v Moldova Kick-off for Scotland v Moldova is at pm on Friday November .The match will take place at Zimbru stadium in Moldova, which is around a  hour flight from Scotland.How can I watch the Scotland v Moldova match on TV The match will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with subscribers able to stream the match throughthe Sky Go app.People who are not Sky customers can watch via NOWTV by buying a day pass for pound..Who is in the Scotland squad Steve Clarke has named a -player strong squad for the World Cup Qualiers.Goalkeepers:Craig Gordon , Jon McLaughlin , Liam Kelly .Defenders:Stephen ODonnell , Nathan Patterson , Jack Hendry , Grant Hanley , Scott McKenna , Liam Cooper ,Kieran Tierney , Andy Robertson .Midfielders:Billy Gilmour , Kenny McLean , Callum McGregor , Stuart Armstrong Stev, David Turnbull , John McGinn , Lewis Ferguson , Scott McTominay ..removeStrikers:Lyndon Dykes , Che Adams , Ryan Christie , Ryan Fraser , Kevin Nisbet .The starting line-up will be announced before the match later today.

title: scotland-v-denmark-kick-off-time-channel-watch-world-cup-qualifier
story: Scotland will play Denmark in their final group stagematch of the World Cup qualiers on Monday night.As it stands, Denmark leads Group F with  points while Scotlandis in second place with ,  points ahead of Israel.Steve Clarkes side will play Moldovaon Friday evening, and a win will mean they guarantee their qualication for the play-offs next year.If they can secure victory over Moldova, it will take the pressure off Scotland for their match against Denmark, who have gone unbeaten so far in the tournament.The top two teams in each group will progress tothe next stage of qualication, with the play-offs taking place in March .With full capacity crowds set toto Hampden Park on Monday night, heres what you need to know about Scotland v Denmark...When is kick off for Scotland v Denmarkmatch Scotland will play Denmark at :pm on Monday November .The match will take place at Hampden Park, Glasgow, making it another home game for Scotland.How can I watch the Scotland v Denmarkmatch on TV The match will be broadcast live on Sky Sports, with subscribers able to stream the match throughthe Sky Go app.People who are not Sky customers can watch via NOWTV by buying a day pass for pound..What position is Scotland currently in Group F as it stands:Denmark:  pointsScotland:  pointsIsrael:  pointsAustria:  pointsFaroe Islands:  pointsMoldova:  pointWhen do the WorldCup play-offs start The play-offs will take place on March  and  .The World Cup in Quatar will start on Monday November  , taking place later in the year than usual due to the high summer temperatures in Doha.

title: send-letters-santa-royal-mail-year--
story: Lettersto Santa can be posted once again this year with Royal Mail, and senders will even receive a reply!Theres no need to try and sendletters up the chimney, just pop it in a post box instead.For -years, Royal Mail has been helping hundreds of thousands of children post their letters to Santa.Heres how you can send Santa letters this year...How to post letters to Santa this year...You can send your letters to Santa this year at the address:Santa Father Christmas,Santarsquos Grotto,Reindeerland,XM HQLetters should be sent by Friday December  to ensure time for response.Make sure to attachfull name and address so senders can receive a reply from Santa.The card from Santa will include a special note from the man himself and a recipe for a gingerbread Buddy the elf recipe.If you cant wait for the response, the card can be downloaded from the Royal Mail website.What are the last datesfor Christmas post Royal Mail is encouraging customers to shop early and post early for Christmas this year.Its latest recommended posting dates for mail to arrive in time for Christmas are:Saturday  Decembernd Classnd Class Signed ForRoyal Mail Tuesday  Decemberst Classst Class Signed ForRoyal Mail Thursday  DecemberSpecial Delivery Guaranteed

title: covid-scotland-need-passenger-locator-form-return-uk
story: Internationaltravel is getting easier after months of uncertainty, however did you know you still have to fill out a passenger locator form Before arriving in the UK, travellers must complete a form detailing where they have been and where they are travelling to.This applies to everyone coming to the UK from abroad, evenyou are only transiting through the country.Heres everything you need to know about filling in the form and travelling to the UK from abroad...What is the passenger locator form You must complete a passenger locator form within-hours before travelling to the UK.Yoursquoll need to show thisform when you check in to travelor board your plane, train or ferry to the UK.If you have not filled out the form, you could be denied travel.The form asks for details of where you have been, vaccination status and where you are going.What do I need to complete the form To complete the form yoursquoll need:your passport details or the travel document yoursquoll use when you arrive at the UK borderyour travel details, including times and datesthe address where you will stay in the UK booking reference numbers for any COVID- tests you must take after arriving in the UKthe invoice number for your quarantine hotel bookingyou need oneto say whether you are vaccinated and where you were vaccinatedYou can fill out your passenger locator form here.What are the current testing rules for ing to the UK from abroad England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are following a four nationsapproach to international travel, meaning the rules for all four countries are the same.If you are fully vaccinatedyou are still required to take a test within two days of arrival in the UK, however this can now be a lateral flow test instead of a PCR test as previously required.Lateral flow tests are cheaper than PCR tests.If you are not fully vaccinated, you must take a test before travelling to the UK, book and pay for tests for day and day  after arrival and quarantine for  days..removeYou will also be required to complete a passenger locator form.

title: leader october 22 2021
story: It is dficult to understand the Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party#s decision not to allow Donald Kelly to represent the party at the  local election – especially when it will not provide a reason.Councillor Kelly said he met #a wall of silence# when asking for a proper explanation or justication, and the Courier has had a similar experience, with numerous attempts to gain answers proving unsuccessful.We asked why the decision was made and why Councillor Kelly was not made aware or given notice of itit was in relation to his Argyll First membership and why support from former Scottish Conservative leaders Annabel Goldie and Ruth Davidson appeared not to be taken into consideration.If we do receive answers to our questions, we will share them with our readers but until then we can only speculate.Surely Councillor Kelly and the people of South Kintyre deserve to know.Congratulations to Fraser Cursiter and Katie Webster who got engaged this week after Fraser proposed on the beach in Carradale.We wish the couple, who are soon moving to Australia, the best of luck for the future we hope theyto visit the place that has earned a special place in their hearts.

title: thought for the week october 22 2021
story: As we crossed the bridge, we were excited to see the island’s beauty.At first though, we had to take our friend’s word for it, as rain, low cloud and failing light obscured most of it from view. The next day the rain stopped, the clouds lted and the sun broke through.We saw for ourselves that what our friend had said was true. Skye’s scenery is stunning.In John, chapter , verses -, the apostles told Thomas that while he had been away, Jesus had physically appeared to them. Thomas refused to accept as true what they told him, insisting that unless he saw him with his own eyes and touched him with his own hands, he would not believe Jesus was alive.For him, seeing was believing.Later, Jesus once again appeared to the apostles and, this time, Thomas was present. Now Thomas believed. Jesus rebuked him for his unbelief and said: ‘Blessed are those who have not seen yet believe.’We believe lots of things, not because we can see them for ourselves but by accepting the word of those who have.Christians believe in Jesus, not because we have seen him with our own eyes, but because of the reliable word of the apostles who physically saw the risen Jesus with their own eyes.I encourage you to read the Gospels, the accurately written-down eyewitness testimony of the apostles to Jesus so that you might see who he is and as you trust in him alone,

title: leader october 29 2021
story: More must be done to prevent the continued spate of thefts which have  blighted Kintyre farms in recent years.To be targeted once must be incredibly frightening but some farmers have been targeted again and again, despite following advice to increase security and lock vehicles away.Maybe now that non-farming vehicles have also been stolen – a van in , a car in March  and another car last week – the wider community may realise the seriousness of the situation.The impact of rural crime takes a huge toll on the mental health of those who live in rural areas like Kintyre, many of whom choose to live here because of the low crime rates.It is therefore heartening that everyone the Courier spoke to in relation to the thefts seems genuinely keen to work collaboratively towards a solution.Parents must make sure their opinions are known about Argyll and Bute Council#s proposal to cluster some Argyll and Bute schools.No matter your opinion –you think an amalgamated Kintyre super-school would create a united front oryou think a dedicated headteacher for each school is better – you must make your voice heard.

title: letters october 29 2021
story: We know this winter is likely to be a dficult one for parents due to the risks caused by Respiratory Syncytial Virusinfections.RSV is a common virus that causes cold-like symptoms but can cause critical illnesses such as bronchiolitis in babies born premature or sick.RSV is usually most prevalent in Scotland between October and March each year.Throughout the Covid- pandemic, restrictions in social contact meant that cases of RSV were reduced. Since people began mixing again, there has steadily been an increase in cases ahead of the usual winter seasonal trend, mainly in children aged under five.Bliss will be working to provide information and support about RSV and respiratory infections directly to families of premature and sick babies at neonatal units across Scotland.We are urging all parents to know the warning signs of respiratory conditions and to contact their health care professional when they need to.In the early stages, RSV symptoms are similar to a common cold .Symptoms usually last between one and three weeks. If the lungs are affected, one or more of the following symptoms will develop or get worse:To find out more, please visit bliss.org.uk RSVA new campaign has been launched urging defibrillator owners to register their devices on a national database to help save more lives from cardiac arrests.Leading charities and health organisations are calling for defibrillators to be registered on The Circuit – the national defibrillator network, which connects defibrillators to NHS ambulance services across the UK.When someone calls  to report a cardiac arrest, call handlers are trained to provide the location of the nearest registered defibrillator within m of the call. Studies show that using a defibrillator within three minutes of collapse, along with starting CPR, can greatly increase chances of survival.This swt action can make a real dference, and The Circuit is a vital tool in helping increase bystander action to help someone in cardiac arrest.We would urge everyone to register the defibrillators that they are responsible for, so that they can be easily located and accessed when needed.It#s free to register your defibrillator onto The Circuit, and you only have to do it once. You can also register multiple defibrillatorsyou areto more than one.Visit www.thecircuit.uk for more information.

title: team nets new bags
story: The purchase of the holdalls was possible thanks to a donation to the under s team from Wylie Hume.#Everyone involved at the s would like to say a massive thanks to Wylie for his kind donation,# said David Paterson, team manager.#As many will know, Wylie himself was heavily involved in the local children#s football association in the s and s and wished to show support to our efforts.#Along with a small payment from parents, rucksacks were also purchased with Campbeltown and District Juvenile Football Association#s help – as is the case for all age groups in the association.#Thanks from all involved at the s.#

title: thought for the week october 29 2021
story: Although the autumn marks the end of summer, for many looking ahead, it#s filled with excitement and anticipation as Christmas approaches. The countdown begins!There are many good things in le we look forward to: a sunny day, a bike ride, the weekend, holidays, retirement or a new job.At dferent times we look forward to dferent things, but behind them all is a common search.The French scientist and mathematician Blaise Pascal said: #All people seek happiness. This is without exception##He said that whatever our idea of how to reach it, our desire never takes the smallest step except towards the goal of happiness it is the desire behind every ambition.But from time to time we recognise our search is misleading, happiness doesn#t last, the clouds come, the ride ends, Monday morning always follows#Three time Wimbledon champion Boris Becker said: #I had won Wimbledon twice before, once as the youngest player. I was rich I had all the material possessions I needed.#It#s the old song of movie stars# they have everything, and yet they are so unhappy. I had no inner peace, I was a puppet on a string.#Where, then, is lasting happiness to be found The bible teaches us that every wonderful thing we enjoy is both a gt and sign pointing us to the giver, our creator God who loves us.If we hope to find ultimate happiness in His gts, we expect too much#We were designed through those gts to enjoy the God who gave them and to find true joy in Him.#I have come [said Jesus] that you may have le and have it to the full.#

title: muddy good rugby festival at taynuilt
story: More than  players from Campbeltown, Lochgilphead, Oban, Fort William, Mull and Taynuilt took part with some fantastic rugby on display across all the age groups from the Micro P-Ps to the P s.Conditions were damp under foot given the amount of rain that has been falling lately. The rain on the day did not dampen the enthusiasm of everyone taking revelling in rolling about in the mud.Congratulations to Kintyre who won both the P  and the P  competitions. They had a real desire to compete and were deserved winners.It was also great to see Mull being represented again after missing the last few festivals and they acquitted themselves well in their first games under their new coaches.A big game of girls touch rugby topped off a great day with all the girls taking part to celebrate Women and Girls in Sport week. This was one of the highlights of the day with the youngest player in P all the way through to the P’sA big thank you to everyone at Etive Vikings for their hospitality. The last festival of the season will take place at Lochaber Rugby Club, Fort William on Sunday November .All pics in D photosMain photograph : Isle of Mull players take a well earned rest.

title: muddy good rugby festival at taynuilt 2
story: Youngsters from the Kintyre-Campbeltown team joined players from Lochgilphead, Oban, Fort William, Mull and Taynuilt, with some fantastic rugby on display across all the age groups from the micro P-Ps to the P-s.Conditions were damp underfoot, given the amount of rain that has been falling lately.But the rain on the day did not dampen the enthusiasm of everyone revelling in rolling about in the mud.#Congratulations to Kintyre who won both the P  and the P  competitions,# said a spokesperson. #They had a real desire to compete and were deserved winners.#It was also great to see Mull being represented again after missing the last few festivals and they acquitted themselves well in their first games under their new coaches.#A big game of girls# touch rugby topped off a great day with all the girls taking part to celebrate Women and Girls in Sport week.This was one of the highlights of the day with the youngest player in P, all the way through to the Ps.The last festival of the season will take place at Lochaber Rugby Club, Fort William on Sunday November .

title: pupils u15s defeated by top of the league team
story: Campbeltown Pupils shosted top-of-the-league Clyde Community s last Sunday, in their first home game in ision one.The Kintyre side has been working hard on the fundamentals of football and managing to hit the mark.Both teams started the game very strong and it was a great first-half from the local side, with the scoreline level at - when the half-time whistle blew.The travelling Clyde side found their feet very quickly in the second half and held a strong back four which the Campbeltown side could not penetrate.With the visitors# scoring three further goals, the final score was Campbeltown Pupils , Clyde Community .

title: spooky sporting activities
story: Participants of both sports dressed up as they took part in activities last Sunday, on October , All Hallows# Eve itself.Paddleboarders dressed up as witches, a cowgirl, Ghostface and sported spooky head boppers as they enjoyed a ride on Campbeltown Loch.And young golfers donned their glow-in-the-dark gear as they took part in an evening competition at Machrihanish Golf Club before changing into their own frightening costumes for a party in the clubhouse afterwards.

title: helping to preserve kintyres coach heritage
story: As well as penning a commemorative piece to mark the th anniversary of the founding of West Coast Motors, bus enthusiast Lawrence Macduff is keeping Kintyre#s coach history alive by preserving one of the company#s vintage vehicles.Lawrence, who splits his time between Kilmarnock and Dunoon, was the author of a three-part commemorate article which featured in the Courier over the last three weeks.It formed the basis for several displays that Lawrence took, along with a newly retired West Coast Motors service coach that he and a friend purchased for preservation just before lockdown, to the Glasgow Vintage Vehicle Trust#s annual open weekend on Saturday October  and Sunday October .Despite Covid restrictions, the newly preserved DAF coach made its maiden show appearance in Dunfermline in August.The information on Campbeltown-based West Coast Motors# history was mounted on to four boards, one featuring an introduction, one covering from the s to , another from  to , and the final board bringing the story to around .They were joined by several other boards concentrated on West Coast Motors# Argyll operations, covering Cowal, Bute, Oban and Mull, what could be called the company#s homeland.

title: leader november 5 2021
story: It can be a bit overwhelming when we are told climate change is #the greatest threat to our existence in our short history on this planet# and that humanity is facing #code red#.As the world#s biggest powers debate the best ways to combat the climate challenges we all face, it would be easy to give up in the belief our inidual actions will have little or no impact on the bigger picture.But the cumulative impact of everyone making a few small changes could have a huge  dference.We don#t all have to rush to buy an electric car – how about buying a reusable cup for your coffee instead of using a disposable plastic cup every day, or turning off lights when leaving a room to help save energy Every little helps.Well done to Beinn an Tuirc Distillers for winning two awards at the Scottish Gin Awards.It is worth noting the distillery#s prizewinning spirits are sustainably produced using the company#s own renewable energy from its small hydro-electric scheme.That means those of us in Kintyre can enjoy a guilt-free tipple as we ponder the challenges of climate change, knowing the gin is produced in an environmentally sustainable way, with low delivery mileage!

title: letters november 5 2021
story: The SNP government#s refusal to heed recommendations from CalMac on how many new ferries the operator required to service its routes has led directly to the crisis that has overtaken Scotland#s ferry service.No fewer than  of CalMac#s  active vessels are now more than  years old, which is the recommended operational lespan of a ferry.A debate on the on-going ferry crisis took place this week at the Scottish Parliament.It was very telling that those SNP members who took part in the debate were quite unable, or unwilling, to launch a defence of their own government#s record when it comes to the crisis affecting our ferry service.They know, as we all do, that SNP ministers have failed in their duty of care to our island communities and that excuses will no longer cut it.Nicola Sturgeon now needs to admit her government#s -year failure to protect our leline ferry service, and then actually do something about it, and quickly.I am appealing for used postage stamps which help me raise funds which I then donate to the Guide Dogs for the Blind.Recycling used postage stamps is such an easy way to raise money for the charity and I am always in need of all types of postage stamps, including British, foreign and Christmas stamps.If you are able to help I would be gratefulyou could cut the stamps from their envelopes, leaving approximately cm margin around the stamp, and send them to: Myrna Chave, PO Box , Virginia Water, Surrey, GU ARThank you to everyone who has donated in the past, your assistance in helping me to support this very worthy cause is greatly appreciated.My email address is stampsgdftb@live for more information.

title: thought for the week november 5 2021
story: There are two kinds of silence.There is the kind that numbs and kills, the kind Simon and Garfunkel sang about.It is the silence imposed upon people – that refuses to hear the cry of the hurt, the wounded, the lonely, the unemployed, the hungry, the vulnerable.Veteransfrom wars, and the daily papers strike glorious attitudes. Suffering from unspeakable trauma, they retreat into silence.Breadwinners lose their jobs, and are condemned to poverty, loss of home, reliance on food banks, endless indignity.Young people struggle with mental illness earth and sea, animal and insect le, struggle beneath the load of pollution – and are met with silence.That silence, the silence of the neon god, breeds lies – lies that threaten our planet, our lives and our souls.But there is a dferent kind of silence: a kindly, warm, nurturing silence.It is the silence of the rich humus of mother earth. It is the amniotic fluid bathing our souls for healing. It is out of that silence alone # the Spirit#s silence # that truth springs, and with truth, justice. And with justice, peace, and the healing touch of love.COP is upon us. Amid all the noisy voices, which kind of silence will we choose  Which kind of silence will we permit  Complicity, or graciousness Mercy and peace have met together,

title: a week of celebrations for argyll booklovers
story: Celebrating its tenth anniversary, Book Week Scotland  will include hundreds of online and in-person events.Supported by Creative Scotland and the Scottish Library and Information Council, the week of events themed around #celebration# will run next week, from November  to .To join in the celebrations, leisure trust liveArgyll will be hosting a series of events across its libraries in Argyll and Bute.Pop into Campbeltown Library for a cuppa and a chat during the library open morning on Saturday November .You will be able to find out what is going on in your local library, from Bookbug to after school clubs, local studies enquiries, the online library BorrowBox and much more.Enjoy a game of Jenga or Connect  with your friends or take part in the Bookbug treasure hunt and seeyou can win yourself a mini Bookbug doll.Running from am to .pm, the event is open to all and is free, just like a library membership.Some of Argyll#s other libraries will welcome Scottish authors in celebration of Book Week.On Tuesday November  from pm to pm, Dunoon Library will host Lin Anderson, author of The Killing Tide: Dark Water, Darker Deeds.And in Oban and Rothesay, booklovers are invited to spend an evening with Scottish crime writing author Alex Gray where she will take them on her writing journey so far, including her newest title Before the Storm.The Oban event will be held at the Studio Theatre at Corran Halls on Wednesday November  and the Rothesay event will be at the Moat Centre on Friday November , both from pm to pm.Helensburgh residents are advised not to miss out on a night of thrills, spills and kills as the town#s library presents An Evening with Chris Brookmyre, who has established himself as one of the UK#s leading crime novelists.This will be held at Helensburgh#s Victoria Halls on Thursday November  from pm to pm.liveArgyll will also be launching its inaugural writing competition for young people during the week of celebrations.All secondary school aged young people in Argyll and Bute are invited to take part, writing a story about Argyll folklore.Visit liveargyll liveargyll-libraries-writing-competition for more information including details on how to enter.

title: pupils prove a point in spirited draw
story: Report by Michael McKinlay in KilsythCampbeltown Pupils showed plenty of guts amidst the gusts last Saturday as theyThe McFadyens-sponsored Pupils won the coin toss and opted to go with the strongThe visitors’ defence worked well to deny any clear opportunities for Kilsyth, while an impressive volleyed effort from Ryan Deans at the edge of the box in the early stages flew over the bar by a few inches.The Kintyre Park side’s goal arrived through a good spell of pressure and possession,His looping cross from deep into six-yard box allowed midfielder Deans to outmuscle a Kilsyth defender and force the ball home.Kilsyth#s equaliser came through a thwarted Pupils counter attack.The Kilsyth midfield quickly sent the ball out to their right winger who found considerable time and space to send a low cross into the box.The hosts’ striker moved well to find himself free and direct the ball into the net from close range.The Feathers-Inn sponsored Pupils made it - when Kilsyth, always keen to play outThe Pupils doubled their advantage before the half-time interval when a set piece fromA defender tripped the Pupils man after he cleverly feinted onto his right side to try create space to shoot.Central defender Ross Souden stepped up and opted to go low to the keeper’s right, only to be denied by the post, possibly with a touch from the goalkeeper, but young striker Conner McMurchy, making his first start for the Pupils, reacted well to pounce on the rebound and finished centrally beyond the recovering keeper, despite his best efforts.Into the second half, Kilsyth came out desperate to reduce the deficit now with wind atThe Pupils were forced into a th -minute substitution with Stuart Crossan, operating well in holding midfield, suffering after a knock in the latter stages of the first half, seeing the welcomeof the Pupils’ versatile left-footer Fraser Wylie.This was followed by the introduction of young Calum Ellis, who replaced McMurchy and continued the visitors’ high work rate up front.Kilsyth pulled a goal back after a sustained period of pressure, a pass from deepA well-timed run from a Kilsyth striker put him one-on-one with keeper Alasdair Ferguson # who was otherwise rarely tested due to an impressive collective work rate off the ball from the Pupils – and the striker slotted home clinically to make it -.The hosts secured an equaliser in the th minute, after a set piece was headed clear, and a home midfielder picked up the loose ball with considerable space to thunder a half volley through the pack of Pupils defenders and straight into the bottom left-hand corner.Pressure continued from the hosts in search of a winner but the Pupils coped well toOne notable goalmouth scramble near end of regulation time was cleared off the Pupils# goal line following good awareness from Liam Renton.A couple of late free kick attempts from Kilsyth failed to trouble Ferguson in goal, who showed good concentration to hold onto one final headed effort before the full time whistle, to end Kilsyth#s  per cent home record.It was an impressive feat for the Pupils, who counted seven teenagers in their -strong squad.Tomorrowthe Pupils are at home to BSC Glasgow, who have been inKick off is pm at Kintyre Park. For more information, find @PupilsAFC on Twitter or Campbeltown Football on Facebook.The Pupils would also like to thank everyone who entered the club’s Last Person

title: a week of celebrations for argyll booklovers 2
story: The event is part of a larger programme offered by LiveArgyll across its libraries in Argyll and Bute.Local literature lovers are invited to pop into Campbeltown Library for a cuppa and a chat during the open day. There will be an opportunity to find out what is going on in your local library, from Bookbug to after school clubs, local studies enquiries, the online library BorrowBox and so much more.Visitors can also enjoy a game of Jenga or Connect  with their friends or take part in the Bookbug treasure hunt and seethey can win themselves a mini Bookbug doll.The open morning runs from am-.pm on Saturday November , is open to all and is free – just like a library membership.Book Week Scotland  will include hundreds of online and in-person events. Supported by Creative Scotland and the Scottish Library and Information Council, the week themed around ‘Celebration’ will run from November –.To join in the celebrations,  Find out more at liveargyll book-week-scotland-.All secondary school aged young people in Argyll and Bute are invited to take part,

title: driving ambition sees youngsters excel in dalriada
story: Mini rugby players from the Kintyre area have hit the ground running during the first half of the   season with a renewed drive from players and coaches alike.Campbeltown Junior Rugby Club took a hit last season not only on the playing field but off the pitch as well with the loss of #Mr Rugby# John Forster.Due to Covid the club weren’t able to play any fixtures and were only allowed to train.At the beginning of this season there was a lot of optimism after having a successful Summer Camp with membership increasing from the previous season.Players and coaches worked hard in training which has been showing in their development from P right through to S level.There was a lot of excitement around the club with the Dalriada tournaments for P-P starting back up. The squads have now completed three rounds with great success with the P #s impressing on their competitive debut.Kicking things off back in September was the Mid Argyll tournament held at the Ropeworks park in Lochgilphead where there were some excellent inidual and team performances from both age groups.In their first experience of a Dalriada the P s equipped themselves very well beating Oban five tries to one and Etive Vikings -.A hard fought game against Mid Argyll saw the Campbeltown Kintyre team narrowly defeatedleaving them a close second in the overall standings.The P s worked hard as a team and this showed in their performances beating ObanIn an entertaining game against the Etive Vikings a last gasp score by the latter meant a - defeat but the Campbeltown outfit took the overall honours and the club#s first ever Dalriada win.The Oban Dalriada was next and after the performances at Mid Argyll confidence was high in both teams.The P s started off well with an excellent team performance to beat Oban -.Mid Argyll were up next and the team were determined to overturn the defeat at the previous tournament and after a hard fought game ran out - winners.The team bounced back in the next two games to beat a mixed Etive Vikings Mull team - and Mull -. Overall they were pipped to the post by Mid Argyll again finishing in second place.Following their previous success the P  team were ready a raring to go and faced their hosts, Oban s in their opener.After a tough game with big tackles and excellent tries from both teams Campbeltown Kintyre ran - victors. Oban s were next and with little break between games another excellent team performance led to a - win.Next up was a mixed Lochaber and Mull team and some well worked tries led to a - win.In the final game against a mixed Etive Vikings and Mid Argyll team tiredness start to show with a couple of uncharacteristic mistakes resulting in a - defeat.Overall Campbeltown Kintyre ran out joint leaders with Oban s.In the most recent Dalriada in Taynuilton Saturday on October  the P s had Mid Argyll in their sights after being beat by their near neighbours twice previously.They didn#t have long to wait for their revenge match as the Lochgilphead-based squad were first up and some great tackles and outstanding inidual efforts saw Campeltown Kintyre get their wish with a - victory.Wins over Mulland Etive Vikingsfollowed and, after falling behind early on, the team fought back for a - draw against Oban.This only left Lochaber and after starting well they never looked back. A - completed their unbeaten run and saw the Campbeltown Kintyre youngsters finish top of the table for the first time.Determined to match their younger clubmates the P  team were equally keen and played some confident rugby to win their matches against Mid Argyll , Etive Vikings , Obanand Oban Sharks .This left a strong Lochaber side between them and achieving their target. After falling behind in the early stages Campbeltown Kintyre dug deep and brought the game back to three tries a piece and with the end of the game drawing near broke away to score the decisive try to also finish undefeated at the top of the table.Mini#s coach Chris Doxsey said: #It has been a brilliant start to the season and one that the club has been building towards for the last six years.#I am so proud of all the players and delighted to be able to be part of a brilliant coaching team and fantastic club.#Thank you to all the parents who have travelled with their children all over Argyll andThe P  team sit top of the overall table with the P  team second on theirs, two points behind Mid-Argyll, going into the final Dalriada in Lochaber on Sunday, November .Campbeltown Junior Rugby Club have opened training up from P through to S and are hoping to start a pre-school club at some point in the future. Anyone interested should contact the club through the Facebook page.

title: kintyre and gigha primaries collaborate for new arts festival
